movie_review_blurb: It wearily welds together nostalgia money lines, the tones of two different movies and some of the most hilarious product placement in cinematic history. Then it throws a dark blue Instagram filter on it and calls it a (very long, disjointed) day.
It's Copley, odious and charismatic, who steals the show, which is obviously the point of casting Sharlto Copley in your hyper-stylized shoot-em-up.
The movie does what it set out to do: entertain its core audience of guys like me who were weaned on Beavis and Butt-head.
Through its powerful emotions coupled with exquisite restraint, this 'small' film makes a big impact.
The psychology feels jarringly anachronistic.
Swarming with ideas, the film never turns schematic or hectoring.
Without the sardonic rant of Philip Roth, upon whose novel the film is based, the material plays as stale or preposterous.
Inarritu and his fellow artists have contrived something wondrous, a formally innovative fugue filled with demons and despair that somehow comes down on the side of life.
Even burdened with flaws demonlover is an original cyber-thriller with a potent message from the ever-surprising and gifted Assayas.
Seldom have grouches, misfits and, yes, nerds seemed so endearing.
Swimming Pool is an entertaining act of provocation that lingers in the mind like iridescent fabric: Turn it one way and it yields this; turn it another and it's a different story.
This full-metal blast at the military is dark, rough-hewn, often hilarious -- and a star-maker for the electric Joaquin Phoenix.
A magically dislocated world quite unlike any current filmmaker's, one that provokes laughter, sadness and uplift all at once.
Tedious exercise in navel-gazing.
Cholodenko has pulled finely calibrated ensemble work from her perfectly cast actors who, despite varied backgrounds, are on the same page and bring a rare authenticity to their interactions.
The film gradually seduces with its mix of dark humor and pathos, poetic, circus-like music, and haunting characters.
Green's refusal to deliver a clear-cut denouement is less a tease or failure of imagination than a haunting truth about wounding love. He has bored deep into the American core and come up with gold.
You leave the theatre buoyed by the image of two men who put conscience before personal safety.
Amply rewards those willing to embrace its austerity.
For its seriousness, high literary aspirations and stunning acting, the film can only be applauded.
Worth watching for its good-humored energy, exposure of social ills, and acting by impeccable pros along with a fabulous newcomer.
Once you downshift to the film's dreamy rhythms, this multiple prize-winner at Cannes and entry in the 2003 New York Film Festival offers modest rewards.
Despite its surface allure and hi-lit cred, the hero remains opaque, the structure is episodic, and the film never quite attains the epic sweep it aspires to.
The film's take on filial love is fresh and affecting. Its political savvy yields sharp insights.
Like few filmmakers, Bertolucci captures ... the sexual delirium of youth.
An innovative ride that carries the viewer into a world familiar from genre films and the novels of Dashiell Hammett, yet quite unlike anything we've seen before.
Its novelistic breadth, pitched intensity and on-the-fly shooting style pull the viewer smack-dab into the middle of these lives.
Preachy, schematic and numbingly predictable.
Miraculously manages to be not merely ferociously partisan, but dramatically compelling and a feast for the minds of moviegoers, not overly nourished these days.
In a triumph of filmmaking, Arnold has endowed a tale of female rage with disquieting social resonance.
A soaring, tragic tale of transcendence and forgiveness that resonates long after the credits roll.
Will prove more compelling as a technical study for Film Studies majors than as an entertainment for a general audience.
This Gallic tourist-porn feels as stale as yesterday's baguette.
It's riveting and on-message, and showcases a new facet of a brilliant actor's burgeoning career.
Clooney confidently lasers away the characters' personal lives to focus on Murrow's maneuverings.
Succeeds as an exercise for the excellent Nichols, even when its theatrical origins fight with the medium of film.
It's Depp, sporting a Scottish accent, who carries the film with his daringly underplayed portrait of a man more at home in idyllic forests and lagoons than his own drawing room.
This is a middling venture destined for English lit courses.
Rises above its own shortcomings through Heath Ledger's electric embodiment of Ned.
This foreign import is more than just a suspenseful wartime story; there's a lack of cynicism, a willingness to embrace human possibility that's as old-fashioned as it is refreshing.
Should be made mandatory viewing in places low and high.
Cuts it as thinking man's sci-fi, and marks another stretch for the ever-fertile Winterbottom.
Offers a startling mix of genres: a memory piece drenched in nostalgia for a lost childhood, clothed in the form of a thriller that grabs you by the throat.
movie_title: I'm Not Scared (Io non ho paura) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A film that brilliantly works the intersection of the personal and the political.
The film raises predictability to new levels.
So murkily executed that the ending is all but indecipherable through the pea-soup.
Miller comes at film with bracing intelligence and a vision both painterly and literary.
In its chicken heart, Crush goes to absurd lengths to duck the very issues it raises.
A wildly funny prison caper.
[Fessenden] weaves a creepy spell by crafting a kaleidoscope of puppetry, sounds and cinema legerdemain.
Even these old pros ... fail to lift a leaden balloon of a movie.
Chouraqui earnestly displays the Balkan horrors till we scarcely react any more to the latest deafening detonation or pile-up of bodies.
Delivers a rewarding story about the return to one's roots and the human potential for renewal.
The film's episodic structure finally proves maddening.
movie_title: Code Unknown (Code inconnu: Récit incomplet de divers voyages) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: The genuine feel-good article.
Thirteen Conversations About One Thing lays out a narrative puzzle that interweaves individual stories, and, like a Mobius strip, elliptically loops back to where it began.
Gooses a creaky genre into new relevance, but it offers no compelling stories and largely wastes the talents of its stellar cast.
Though fancifully constructed, Happenstance is principally the visualization of a concept, and in the end, more of a moving board game than a movie.
It's dispiriting to see the French relinquish all irony and attempt to out-schlock the Americans.
Demands too much of most viewers.
movie_title: Ni na bian ji dian (What Time Is It Over There?) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Throughout this aerial confection, 'real life' and artifice are intriguingly intertwined.
Lacking any center, in its pandering heart the movie tries to be something for everyone.
Though Tran places special demands on his viewers, those prepared to enter his magical world will hunger to return.
movie_title: The Vertical Ray of the Sun (Mua he chieu thang dung) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: An entertaining and provocative tale of ordinary people who suddenly find themselves heroes.
A low-budget, deceptively minimalist drama that delivers big.
While Breillat's latest does not exactly qualify as entertainment, it makes the unwatchable something we want dearly to watch.
Montiel's first effort remains episodic and inward, failing to build a bridge to the viewer.
movie_title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A spunky, original take on a theme that will resonate with singles of many ages.
Though certainly original in form, Altar Boys requires a taste for Swamp Thing-type animation, doubled with a deafening score.
movie_title: The Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys (2002)

movie_review_blurb: More whiny downer than corruscating commentary.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Money (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Open-ended and composed of layer upon layer, Talk to Her is a cinephile's feast, an invitation to countless interpretations.
A sustained fest of self-congratulation between actor and director that leaves scant place for the viewer.
A marvel of production design.
Why did such fine actors sign on to this lollapalooza?
Its keenly observed set-pieces never add up to a larger picture.
A guilty pleasure, like chocolate truffles.
Bravely explores the psychic damage inflicted on Jean-Luc by a withholding, then absent parent.
movie_title: Comment j'ai tué mon père (My Father and I) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Let's salute Rohmer's ability at 81 to bend the latest technology to his unique cinematic vision.
The characters are more deeply thought through than in most 'right-thinking' films.
Chabrol brilliantly conjures menace from the everyday and familiar.
Though not much seen on these shores, Italian cinema, to judge by The Last Kiss, is alive and well.
Part of the film's cheeky charm comes from its vintage schmaltz.
movie_title: The Kid Stays in the Picture (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Consistently entertaining, with witty dialogue and a kind of Gallic concision, shaved of superfluous moments.
While you could never fault Sayles for speedy exposition, the donkey-cart pace makes you want to whip the thing along.

With a small budget and a brilliant team, director/co-writer Jonathan Parker has brought new relevance to Bartleby's revolt, and converted an office sitcom format into a damning critique of the way many people spend their days.
Anderson brilliantly conjures a goofy, skewed world as seen by a hyper kid.
Tweaking genre convention at every turn, Taylor has created a shimmering entertainment that leaves you, well, humming 'Cherish.'
Apparently writer-director Attal thought he need only cast himself and his movie-star wife sitting around in their drawers to justify a film.
For all its Sundance cool factor, the latest from this gifted director glances off the viewer without leaving much impact.
Offers up a brave, spot-on portrait of one man pulverized by the system during the Watergate era.
This powerful film celebrates individual acts of conscience in barbarous times.
Sharply observed, often LOL comedy about artistic integrity and the shrinking horizons of middle age.
Exercising spectacular control, director David Cronenberg permits not a single iota of humanity or altruism to sneak into this twisted tale.
A nuanced, humanistic portrait of a town besieged by jihadists, its images of violence suffused with almost surreal dreaminess.
In the marvelous, immersive A Most Violent Year, [J.C.] Chandor broadens his canvas, proving himself a major filmmaking talent.
Timothy Spall etches an indelible portrait of the great painter, aided by a marvelous supporting cast who make the period spring alive.
The auteur's unbeatable weirdness here mutates into preciosity.

But Stevens and Katz give naturalism a bad name by making it boring. Land Ho! intends to affirm that even for the graying population, life offers surprises, renewals, fun. Sadly, they're only experienced by the gents onscreen.

In its focus both on the looming disaster of climate change and the swelling economic disparity between the rich and everyone else, it's both timely and relevant, while keeping the entertainment quotient high.
Madding Crowd will remind viewers of how hungry they are for an epic romance minus the cynicism and snark.
This pungent comedy set in combat's erogenous zone is Polanski at the top of his game.
The Double draws on past literary giants to nail a current malaise with offbeat humor and visionary flair.
This brilliant dissection of family dynamics and the tyranny of the past weds honesty with slow-burn drama and peerless acting.
Despite the offbeat-pun intended-casting, in Kill Your Darlings the richly gifted Krokidas delivers a terrific entertainment which updates this origin story with its stinging critique of homophobia.
And though the plot is wafer-thin, 'Bodies' is less about story than mood and visual poetry, playing like a folk ballad about criminal lovers.
A way-cool account of a real-life crime spree in Southern California that trips on Sofia Coppola's failure to take a directorial stance.

This third chapter hits new highs as Richard Linklater gets down and dirty about the challenges of long-term commitment. The ongoing saga of Jesse and Celine makes for one of the most engaging love stories in contemporary cinema.
A genre-twisting documentary with a fictional vibe that playfully bares the elusive truths about a family of storytellers.
Departing her trademark dramas, noted Danish filmmaker Susanne Bier remixes the rom-com in a sparkling cocktail that celebrates the messiness of life.

Filth, another wild ride drawn from Irvine's fiction, will likely appeal only to diehard proponents of the writer's dystopian vision. Complicating the issue, though, is the performance of James McAvoy, which is nothing short of extraordinary
The period detail is perfect and the lensing nails the novel's frenzied rhythms, but a literal-minded approach and miscast lead stall this baby before the finish line.
A lovely addition to Ken Loach's cinema of working-class heroes, this true story of Irish agitator James Gralton is intelligent, gorgeously shot, and makes the heart sing.
A screwball comedy from a master filmmaker reaches moments of inspired pandemonium, but a plot centered on lecherous men quickly palls.
Trafficks in exploitative images of women in the guise of art-film license.
[A] blistering and timely account of the privileged classes, relayed with dark humor and impeccable craft.
Mingles realism and the surreal to convey the immorality of war.
Oh hell, it's refreshing to see a woman give a man a taste of his own Don Juan.
movie_title: Lover For A Day (L'amant d'un jour) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: This Palme d'Or winner is a meaty film of ideas with instant-classic set-pieces and moments of mind-blowing freakiness, a stunning follow-up to Force Majeure.
Coasts mainly on surfaces. Issues and questions are raised, grazed, but remain unexplored.
Brad Pitt nails it as a four-star general out to win an unwinnable war in this savage, often hilarious but tonally uneven satire skewed at thinking adults.
A well-crafted bagatelle about the self-renewal of a neglected wife that hits all the Screenwriting 101 points.
Lacks narrative heft and momentum.
An elegant anthem to one man's effort to make sense of a tortuous past and achieve closure, anchored by mesmerizing turns from Jim Broadbent and Charlotte Rampling.
A moving if somewhat elusive meditation on human aloneness and independent women at odds with their environment.
A misfire from distinguished stage director Michael Grandage about the artistic and emotional interplay between Thomas Wolfe and fabled Scribner's editor Maxwell Perkins.
A delicious marriage of Whit Stillman and Jane Austen in a comedy of manners with a contemporary spin that delights from start to twisty finish.
Ralph Fiennes steals the show in a riveting erotic thriller from the director of I Am Love about a foursome up to no good on a Mediterranean getaway.
Golden Days [...] feels too insular, as if created for [director Desplechin] and a circle of intimates, rather than the rest of us sitting out there in the dark.
movie_title: My Golden Days (Trois Souvenirs De Ma Jeunesse) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A stunning cinematic achievement thanks to gifted director Andrew Haigh, who pulls indelible turns from Brit screen legends Charlotte Rampling and Tom Courtenay.
At once visually stunning and a candidate for the season's most irritating and pretentious work.
An old-school, emotionally soaring take on an Irishwoman's new life in America, interrupted by the lure of the old sod, featuring a star-making turn by Saoirse Ronan.
A scalding, perfectly wrought film about a man's struggle to assert his dignity in a bureaucratic system that's rigged to destroy it.
In this classy, immersive drama, a renowned string quartet must recalibrate following the illness of its patriarch.
Foxcatcher weaves its spell through the cunning use of unhurried silences...-rarely does a director display such control of his materials.
A heat wave draws a group of New Yorkers into a ring of seduction and desire in this shoddy exercise marked by posturing and pretention.
A bold, riveting tale of wartime resistance borrowing the form of a noir thriller.
movie_title: Flammen & Citronen (Flame & Citron) (The Flame and the Lemon) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A bold, riveting tale of wartime resistance borrowing the form of a noir thriller.
movie_title: Flammen & Citronen (Flame & Citron) (The Flame and the Lemon) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: In this brilliant and provocative chamber piece, the ever-inventive Steven Soderbergh captures the life of a high-end call girl, equating it with the entrepreneurs she services.
Gregor Jordan and Bret Easton Ellis take no prisoners in this uncompromising, expertly crafted shocker about hedonism in early-'80s L.A.
This reunion of old college friends gets a leaden treatment in what is effectively a one-act play posing as a film.
Tom Tykwer's globe-spanning thriller about corporate malfeasance offers ideas, pace, beauty, and an aces turn from thinking-man's action hero Clive Owen.

Recreating true events, this rousing, impeccably lensed World War II drama depicts Jewish partisans battling Nazis in the woods of Belarus, with Daniel Craig and Liev Schreiber outdoing themselves as heroic fighters.
For those willing to enter its dangerous world, the rewards of this film are great.
This collage of vignettes breathes life into New York's edgy lovers.
At film's end, we happily say adieu to a pair who deserve each other more than they imagine.
[Moore] turns potentially dry material into a film that's funny, poignant, and a call to arms.
Those willing to stay with this often demanding film, though, will find an unusually balanced view that celebrates not only Mariane's courage, but the Pakistanis who fought valiantly on her behalf.
Southern pulp trash centered on a miscarriage of justice during the Civil Rights era that's wildly entertaining due to fearless turns from Nicole Kidman, John Cusack and a half-naked Zac Efron.
Pacey and entertaining, it's anchored by a zesty turn from Richard Gere, and it deftly evokes, through music and news clips, the early '70s of Nixon and anti-war protests.
This film leaves you hoping for a project truly worthy of Gordon-Levitt's gifts.
The film generates such visceral heat, the whole notion of genre becomes irrelevant.
The film will likely divide viewers, striking many as a self-indulgent wallow, others as a rewarding envelope-pusher. In fact, it combines elements of both.
Viewers here can't help but respond to the raw emotions and acting ability of the largely nonprofessional cast.
Even the lineup of superlative thesps can't mask the pandering, manipulative ploys at the film's cheesy heart.
This original but overlong fable about a family menaced by industrial progress captures fears about a planet out of control.
David Duchovny as the writer delivers a turn so listless and bland, you want to goose him with a cattle prod.
Unscrolling at the intersection of high art, drama and sex, Coco Chanel & Igor Stravinsky brings a pair of legends to vibrant life.
This psychological thriller from Argentine Juan José Campanella boasts a fine cast and spiky dialogue, but thematic bloat blunts its power.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A rich, multi-strand excursion into fatherhood, creativity and desire anchored by a dream cast and set amidst offbeat Venice locales.
A seductive if uneven attempt to bring to the screen a cult novelist's vision of young love.
A reunion of four college friends sheds little light on the male psyche in this garbled and unwatchable film
This riveting, knockout punch of a film about a sex addict works the intersection of art, tone poem and social critique.
This shivery account of the fallout from a creepy cult on a young woman deftly combines the horror-thriller genre with naturalistic drama and marks the arrival of a gifted young director.
This indie gem explores with uncommon insight the eroding effects of long distance on love.
A dour Nordic humor informs this small but appealing comedy of couples in crisis in the snowy North.
In a remarkably assured debut, Mike Cahill and Brit Marling, his star and co-writer, churn a mesmerizing tale of redemption through a sci-fi premise about a twin planet.
A riveting, deftly crafted sci-fi thriller that plays mind games with the viewer.
Gifted newcomer Richard Ayoade delivers a delightfully edgy romp about first love, styled as a home movie and diary, and starring Craig Roberts in a career-making turn.
Lovers of Charlotte Bronte's classic will luxuriate in the spooky Gothic atmosphere, but the film's pallid Jane fails to nail a character who changed how women view themselves.

From venerable French filmmaker Alain Resnais comes a trippy, genre-bending meditation on the vagaries of passion that widens the boundaries of cinema, but engages the intellect more than the emotions.
...it's refreshing to encounter a deeply involving film unafraid of raw, visceral emotion, a film that for once thinks almost too big.
Powerful, raw and fluidly shot, this history of a marriage told in shuffled time stars Michelle Williams and Ryan Gosling, two of our finest young actors.
A blistering, eye-opening documentary with the potential to change America.
Soaring visuals of the mighty mount combine with a portrait of intriguing George Mallory to hit a new peak in adventure filmmaking.
movie_title: The Wildest Dream: Conquest of Everest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: With newspapers going bankrupt country-wide, director Andrew Rossi offers an up-close view of the players, stories and struggles at America's paper of record, making a persuasive case for traditional newsgathering
movie_title: Page One: Inside the New York Times (2011)

movie_review_blurb: In this lumbering farce with maudlin top notes, a group of displaced Russian musicians attempt to reclaim their former glory.
With its brilliant cinematography by Ennio Guarnieri and cast of pretty faces, the film is like a painting come to life.
movie_title: Brother Sun, Sister Moon (Fratello sole, sorella luna) (1972)

movie_review_blurb: Jake told us kids that what we always suspected was true: the summer of love was dead, long live the summer of the shark.
For Bava as for Daibolik, aesthetic beauty and tactile sensation trump emotional connection and spiritual depth.
An intelligent look at a time when the old guard of tough-talking gumshoes and snappy reporters were about to surrender to a new breed: educated and self-aware men and women.
The film never delivers on its morbid promise, thanks to the character's too-obscure motives and dialogue that's dull when it should be snappy.
The layered script is alternately hilarious and realistic, horrifying and stilted.
This mushy tale of twenty-something angst is like a Euro version of Reality Bites.
Malkovich squeezes the most from his exotic locations, and the intriguing performances give a human face to its topical subject.
Like a creaky roller coaster, you feel it could fall apart at any time.
Spoiled 20-somethings waxing nostalgic over failed relationships rarely makes compelling viewing for anyone over the legal drinking age, and XX/XY is no exception.
Provokes thought and provides joy in equal measure.
At his best, Griffin recalls a young Richard Pryor.
It's Farrell's portrayal of the smug publicist that turns the improbably absurd premise into weird, pulpy fun.
Victor and Judy are so appealing and realistic in their lead roles that you'll swear you're watching a documentary.
[Rock's] off-the-wall sense of humor and genuinely likable persona overcome his lack of finesse behind the camera.
If you're a parent ... this isn't a bad 75-minute distraction for the little ones.
A film about people who feel too much for people who don't think too much.
Much of the digitally altered footage appears jagged, as if filmed directly from a television monitor, while the extensive use of stock footage quickly becomes a tiresome cliché.
A pleasant enough romp, but it succumbs to a one-note script that restricts the film's characters from taking advantage of much of its potential hilarity.

The source and the subject matter make it difficult to assign critical judgement to Blind Spot, but the film's snail pace means it will probably appeal mostly to scholars and students of the Holocaust.
Your enjoyment of National Security will be in direct proportion to how much you can tolerate Martin Lawrence's antics.
The so-inept- it's-surreal dubbing (featuring the voices of Glenn Close, Regis Philbin and Breckin Meyer) brings back memories of cheesy old Godzilla flicks.
In the end, viewers will find sympathy for even a low-life like Brogan -- one of the film's many ambiguities that will linger long after the projection bulb has dimmed.
Combining elements of 1984, Fahrenheit 451 and The Matrix, this ridiculous sci-fi mish-mash sounds appealing, but is nothing more than a poorly designed knockoff.
Parallels to Stanley Kubrick's 2001 abound, and Clooney's portrayal of a man offered the opportunity to escape into a world of dreams might be the actor's best work to date.
Robert Harmon's less-is-more approach delivers real bump-in -the-night chills -- his greatest triumph is keeping the creepy crawlies hidden in the film's thick shadows.
The riveting performances by the incredibly flexible cast make Love a joy to behold.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Money (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Suffers from a flat script and a low budget.
It's just plain boring.
The film's premise -- that the savvy student played by Charlotte Ayanna would get involved with this creep -- is a stretch at best.
You want explosions, expertly choreographed violence and implausible situations easily remedied by running up a wall and doing a back flip? Cradle delivers the goods.
We've seen it all before.
With a surprisingly resonant emotional undercurrent, this adult relationship comedy comes off as extremely likable, if not lovable.
A perfect date movie for jaded Francophiles.
A compelling slice-of-life narrative that draws much of its strength from its non-professional actors.
Remains compelling even at over two-and-a-half hours thanks to great performances from Law, Zellweger and the collection of cameo appearances from the likes of Giovanni Ribisi and Hoffman.
Serviceable performances from the principals underscore the film's functionality, giving modern star power to its paint-by-numbers plot.

This breezy remake of the 1987 film Can't Buy Me Love is so lightweight it threatens to float off the screen, but likable performances from leads Cannon and Milian go far in helping anchor some of writer/director Troy Beyer's flimsy script.
Dwells in its own abysmal dreariness without creating real suspense, relying instead on a stream of easy shocks to convince us that we're watching a scary movie.
A strangely grim affair that will stretch the patience of more than a few viewers.
The filmmakers should've left this story on the bookshelf.
Busch is actually pretty great as Arden, but with nothing to hang his wig on, it all gets tiresome rather quickly, inviting unflattering comparisons to John Waters' superior 1980 effort, Polyester.
Ultimately pointless, this lethargic picture seems to be trying to make a statement but succumbs to its own artiness -- including a cast made up mostly of non-actors.
This sappy, overlong, three-hankie melodrama featuring Gooding Jr. in full-on Rain Man mode is about as corny as they come.
Ignore the Irish fiddle and tin-whistle score and settle in for a compelling and intense story.
A touching tribute to a community celebrating life in the face of tragedy and death.
Not aspiring to be much more than a simple fish-out-of-water comedy, Elf is sweet and a little hokey -- and has the makings of a holiday classic.
The location camerawork and story are outstanding, but amateurish acting and editing keep this dreamy mess from feeling like a proper movie.
Filmgoers may debate its allegory and sexual politics, but 28 Days Later is the real deal: a scary flick for uncertain times.
Surprisingly low on laughs considering the talent involved.
Writer-director Jed Weintrob is so busy trying to make important statements about human relationships in the cyber age that he loses control of his whiny, unlikable characters.
This coming-of-age drama, based on the Dodie Smith novel, has the feel of a proper BBC production, but it lacks the energy to compel on the big screen.
The likeable characters and silly situations create a few genuine laughs and the liberal sexual content (by American standards) is surprisingly refreshing.
Gator's gradual transition from smirking punk to neon-clad cheeseball is vividly told by his former friends and contemporaries.
movie_title: Stoked: The Rise and Fall of Gator (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately, a logjam of characters (nearly all from the book are included) means that few get the attention they deserve.
A bit long and pretentious at times, Carnage is still an interesting narrative experiment that recalls some of the more avant garde Eastern European cinema from the early '70s.

Satoshi Kon and Sadayuki Murai have dispensed with many of the conventions that plague Japanese anime to create an original and compelling animated fantasy that satisfies as both a historical romance and a philosophical drama.
Winterbottom ... proves he's one of the most talented, dexterous filmmakers around with this powerful drama.
Nielsen, Chloe Sevigny and Gina Gershon shine, but ultimately this stylish yet dated arthouse feature is more confused than we are.
Uneven yet often hilarious.
