"Red Army" deserves a wide audience and should even play better for those who don't care one iota about hockey, mostly because it's so entertaining and character-driven.
In some ways, it feels like a throwback to many '80s teen movies, where everything comes down to a competition at the end, and the hero will finally get the chance to prove his worth.

There are strong elements and ideas at work in "Spring," and the filmmakers certainly have our attention moving forward. It seems, though, that they're still finding their voice and how to best communicate their good ideas.
It's slight and enjoyable, but falters a bit as it strains for profundity.
It feels unfinished, and unnecessarily padded by melodramatic plot developments and some strange, creepy exploitation of its young actress.
At times it comes to life, but for the most part it's a bit one-note and repetitive.
While not as mind-blowing or surprising as "Killing," "The Look of Silence" is perhaps the more necessary film.
The sentiment and narrative are solid if not a little boilerplate, but the greatest accomplishment is its totally convincing world-building.
Du Welz could grow into a truly singular voice in pulp world cinema.
A pretty straightforward account of Boenish's life and tragic death, but man... all those skydiving, cliff-jumping and parachuting shots are really something to behold.
"Alleluia" works best late at night, where the spindly tendrils of its bizarro narrative can seep into a less lucid, exhausted brain, one that's far more susceptible to its (anti) charms.
Apatow and Bonfiglio do a fine job creating a portrait that should satisfy fans and serve as an inviting introduction to those who don't know the Avett's classic American music.
movie_title: May It Last: A Portrait of the Avett Brothers (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A daring and emotional documentary.
It's an old school spy story and a good one.
Robert Bresson's first feature, Les Anges du péché is a fascinating film, both intrinsically and in its relation to the rest of Bresson's oeuvre.
Good science fiction almost always holds a mirror up to present-day society and quite often, we may not like what we see.
Marshall aims simply to scare the bejesus out of audiences with scenes of shocking brutality and mayhem that linger long after the credits roll.
Burdened by a distinctly "been there, done that" vibe that I can't imagine will generate much excitement, even with the kiddies.
If you had the choice of doing "crank" or seeing the film Crank, I'd strongly suggest the former as a more productive use of your time.
La La Land remembers when movies were magical and fun, blending nostalgia and contemporaneity in a candy-sweet love letter to cinema.
Chevalier emerges as that fascinating and seemingly paradoxical thing: a feminist film in which women are virtually absent from the screen.
Weighted by good intentions, Ryan turns a potentially riveting story of two lost souls shaken by trauma into a sappy teen drama.
Despite its split personality, Hurricane offers more good than bad, including a lively soundtrack featuring Benoit, the Neville Brothers and Fats Domino.
The real hook is Neelkanth, who serves as a compelling guide and evolves into a great Hindu leader.
A lovely but sedate version of Scaturro and Brown's history-making adventure.
Thanks to specially built equipment, audiences are treated to a bug's-eye view of the stars' evolution from adolescence to adulthood.
Overall, the producers do a nice job balancing beautiful scenery with a serious message.
The film will appeal to Discovery Channel fans and will surely widen the perspective of those of us who see the continent through rose-colored glasses.
A comic fiasco!
Even as the movie provides much-needed positive images of black men and youths, it's also marred by an abundance of cliches and God-awful dialogue.
Quote not available.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Goofy entertainment.
Despite its flaws, the Handmaiden is worth a watch for its complex female characters, its captivating plot, and the gorgeous costumes and scenery.

Gerwig will make you feel for her even as you cringe at her terrible decisions. But best of all is Julianne Moore as an over-the-top Danish anthropologist -- a character more like her comedic turn in 30 Rock than any of her recent dramatic roles.
Rauch's character could easily be too cutesy, too cruel, or just too annoying if played by another actress. But audiences will love her particular brand of arrested development.
Ruth Negga's performance is the best part of the film; she is all quiet determination, seeing the larger implications of her case when her husband does not.
Hilarious, touching, and thought provoking, this is a joyous celebration of punk music, female friendship, and, most of all, 13-year-old girls.
Assayas uses the supernatural to explore grief, and Stewart portrays Maureen's heartbreaking loneliness with skill. She completely carries the film.

Chastain gives a strong performance and is helped along by a script by Angela Workman that, along with Niki Caro's direction, puts Antonina, a far more interesting character than any of the others, right where she should be: at the center.

Much of what's interesting about Dickinson comes from her written work, and while writer/director Terence Davies attempts to derive drama from her day-to-day life, he fails to create a captivating story.
Belle becomes the perfect movie for anyone who loves period romances, but wishes they were a little more diverse.
Director Sophia Takal makes some interesting choices, but ultimately, the story doesn't quite come together

Rebecca Hall's performance is incredible. Her Christine is awkward, full of nervous energy, and impossible to look away from. But Campos missed an opportunity to fully explore Christine's mental-health challenges.
Kristen Wiig, Melissa McCarthy, Leslie Jones and Kate McKinnon are all absolutely, brilliantly hilarious -- I couldn't tell you which one made me laugh the most.
These characters are all fully realized and a lot of fun to watch, but so many of them get just one or two scenes -- especially the women.
If you're looking for a movie with complex female characters exploring female friendship -- and of course you are! -- Happy Christmas is definitely worth seeing.
Not every gag completely works, but there's enough genuinely funny writing here to keep audiences laughing throughout the movie's 83 entertaining minutes.
Caplan and Brie deserve a much better movie than this.
Beautifully shot -- the girls' constantly-changing hair colors are often a focal point -- All This Panic is a quiet, often-heartbreaking reminder of what it's like to be a teenage girl.
For all its laughs, In A World... isn't short on messages or touching moments.

Though Johansson barely speaks, she conveys her alien character's unfamiliarity with her body and her surroundings, as well as her growing awareness of what it means to be human, in every look and subtle motion.
I'll give the Neon Demon this: while it's nowhere near perfect, it's certainly interesting and unique.
Beautifully shot and pleasantly rambling.
Clea DuVall's directorial debut, The Intervention, brings together so many of our favorite actors for a break-up-and-make-up dramedy.

I enjoyed the remake but it definitely has its flaws, and nothing beats the original movie. Additionally, the remake worked for me because I grew up with the original and it was hitting the nostalgia feels HARD.
If you love romantic dramas, or YA novels, or Amandla Stenberg, or visually creative films, then see this movie.
Tamblyn has a unique perspective as a director, and we're excited to see what she creates next.
If you don't know much about activist Wilma Mankiller, now's the time to change that.
Half Magic's dialogue can sometimes be heavy-handed, but its over-the-top nature helps make the movie fun.
Gina Rodriguez and Tessa Thompson especially stand out, and though they get a decent amount of screentime, I wanted even more.

It's an interesting take on a romance plot, but while Ben is definitely cute, he and Diana have no real chemistry - I didn't particularly care why they broke up or if they'd get back together, which meant that the story as a whole didn't hold my interest.
Though Star Trek fans might enjoy the references, Please Stand By fails mainly because it doesn't depict Wendy's autism with any realism or nuance.
Kruger gives a devastating performance as a woman torn apart by grief and rage.

Some scenes are visually beautiful, and Blanchett is of course brilliant, but unless you're deep into art theory or a Cate Blanchett completist, I'd advise rewatching Elizabeth, or I'm Not There, or both, instead.
... puts a powerful, post-Monica-Lewinsky-TED-Talk spin on the concept of public shaming.
McDormand stands out in a sea of stellar performances-more than anything else, Three Billboards is a reminder that she should be starring in movies at least as regularly as Meryl Streep.
... The Center Will Not Hold is well worth watching, both for Didion fans and for those who want an introduction to her work and her writing.
movie_title: Joan Didion: The Center Will Not Hold (2017)

movie_review_blurb: ... it's a beautiful coming-of-age story that hasn't been told before.
Faces Places is a celebration of Varda for fans of her work, and a strong introduction for those who haven't yet watched her films.

It's hard to imagine a film that more thoroughly passes the Bechdel Test than Novitiate, a period drama about nuns coming to terms with the changes Vatican II brought to the Catholic Church in the 1960s.

Tore than a love story, this is a story about Kumail's relationship with two sets of parents, his own and Emily's -- and both are full of conflicts that range from hilarious to frustrating to incredibly sweet.
Jenny Slate's performance is fantastic, as are Edie Falco's, Abby Quinn's, and the rest of the cast. Make sure to bring a lot of Kleenex to this one.
Having a female action star isn't enough to make a film feminist, and like so many other action films, Atomic Blonde falls short in how it portrays women, and how it portrays same-sex relationships.
Cowperthwaite isn't doing anything particularly original with this film, but dog lovers will find it an enjoyable watch.
Director Nicole Garcia creates a romantic drama that at times falls back on clichés, but also covers new ground with a love-it-or-hate-it unexpected ending.
movie_title: From the Land of the Moon (Mal de pierres) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Though you'll recognize familiar tropes, [Natalia] Leite's direction and Dianna Agron's performance mean that Bare is interesting in a way that feels new.
Dolores argues that Huerta should have a much bigger place in American history - here's hoping that this documentary can help make that happen.
The Incredible Jessica James isn't reinventing the rom-com, but it doesn't need to. It's sweet, smart, and funny, and makes me want to see Jessica Williams star in all of the things.
Quote not available.
Lame scatalogical gags and worn pop-culture parodies abound, but the CGI animation romp is somewhat redeemed by the scene-stealing appearances of several supporting characters.
As Downtown plods toward its Christmas Eve-set climax, the film's tendency to OD on melodrama detracts from its grittier moments.
We're forced to endure plenty of scatological gags and treacly exchanges between Shane and his distant dad as the film imparts an obvious message about the frivolity of stardom.
Like a first snow, Mark Fergus's psychological thriller is unpredictable, but doesn't quite stick.
If you missed the money-isn't-everything message, an end-credits recap outlines the story's salient points -- if you'd known, you could've skipped the rest.
Quote not available.
The Swiss-quartz comic timing of the film's ensemble cast makes its neurotic characters more compelling than your average cinematic slackers.

Run All Night might not be original or a message movie or even a film that will be debated during the drive home, but action fans won't want to be anywhere else for one hour and 54 minutes in a theater.
If the gender roles were reversed, the seduction scenes would be considered exploitative and creepy.
Home isn't a bad movie at all; it just lacks that intangible "it" factor found in the most successful animated films.
Cloying but satisfying.
Forget the whole "Whatever happens in Vegas stays in Vegas" spiel; Officer Blart should have done us all a solid and stayed in Jersey with his Segway.
That's why this is the rare sequel that knocks it out of the park; director Danny Boyle isn't trying to reinvent the wheel.

The plotting ranges from predictable to ridiculous and with the exception of a handful of laugh-out-loud moments, Dempsey's frequent shirtlessness is the film's main appeal. The rest is as unpalatable as stale wedding cake.

The best horror films have always reflected the times. The provocative, energising Scream 4, however, goes one better: it doesn't just mirror the times, it boldly refutes them, throwing down a big, bad middle finger salute to a world gone seemingly crazy.

Branagh succeeds in making Thor accessible, coherent and engaging. He takes something that could have potentially been silly, and crafts it into a big, grand, visually impressive slab of superhero cinema.

While not quite in the league of, say, The Empire Strikes Back or the film that it amusingly references with its title, The Godfather Part II, The Hangover Part II really is a sequel to savour... right to the bottom of the bottle.
Gripping, intelligent, richly characterised and superbly performed, the latest entry into the comic book cinematic landscape is nothing short of utterly brilliant.
While it wears its cinematic influences on its sleeves, this is a true original, creating a world that feels utterly real, exciting and wonderfully nostalgic.
Malick resides largely in his own vivid imagination and overly active subconscious, where it's just too easy for everybody else to get resolutely and inescapably lost.
Perfectly positioning its blockbuster action within a thought-provoking framework, this smart and emotionally involving sci-fi drama deserves its own string of sequels.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Nispel certainly succeeds in making a gutsy, ballsy, bloody action-adventure flick worthy of its central character's towering, archetypal mythos.
Driven by James Marsh's measured storytelling style, this ethically unsettling and emotionally compelling documentary is the equal of any cinematic epic.
Thematically rich and brilliantly performed, this is compelling and entertaining viewing, and also has something worth saying.
A funny, candid and emotionally affecting portrait of one of heavy metal rock's most unpredictable legends.
a film so tough, anguished and emotionally devastating that you can safely assume that Kondracki has scratched words like "compromise" and "safe" from her personal vocabulary.
While it's let down by its reliance on action genre clichés, this remains compelling and thought-provoking throughout.
Unfortunately, however, the film mainly shows that if you give a filmmaker the world, he often won't have the necessary skills to navigate it.
An unusual but absolutely absorbing work which bravely tackles the big questions with thoughtfulness and real emotion.
Driven by pitch-perfect performances and a real sense of reverence for the western, this marks another extraordinary achievement for the Coens.
Despite the talent involved, this ends up an underwhelming superhero flick marred by dull action and non-existent chemistry between the cast.

In its sweet, understated, but deeply meaningful story about making vital connections in an often desperately vacuous world, Sofia Coppola proves that, yes, she might have it all, but she still knows what's important in life.
Tight, economic, exciting and strongly performed, Red Hill is a truly auspicious debut.
Dinner For Schmucks is hilariously entertaining. Its pointed messages, meanwhile, make it even more meaningful.
While a rock solid piece of entertainment, this may have been something special if the focus had been shifted to Gordon Gekko.
While its premise is a painful one, this warm, surprisingly funny and deeply touching film never feels maudlin.
Gratuitous explosions, fight scenes and macho stars past and present, this is the pick of this year's cluttered action crop.
A compelling and intelligent horror film which twists genre conventions to deliver something excitingly new.
From the actresses gamely doing their own singing, to the grubby, fumbling sex scenes, The Runaways breathlessly seethes with hard fought authenticity.

Boasting fine supporting turns (Peter Sarsgaard and Viola Davis are both excellent), perfectly placed twists and turns, and enough star-shine to power a small city, Knight And Day is big time entertainment, with a capital E.

Boldly enlivened by its risque, full-force approach to drugs and sex, Get Him To The Greek is comedy gold, but it's the film's serious centre (principally its commentary on addiction and relationships) that makes it even more memorable.

Though he films his action scenes in the increasingly annoying modern style (namely, shooting them so frantically that you can't actually tell what's going on in the frame), Joe Carnahan hits just the right balance of fun and fury here.
Taut, suspenseful and finely acted, this delivers both thrills and strong characterisation.
It may adhere to the original a little too closely, but this remake is still an immensely enjoyable ride boosted by Craig Brewer's pitch-perfect musical instincts.
Rich with ideas, and driven by extraordinary visuals, the occasionally confusing but deeply rewarding 'Oblivion' is a top-flight slice of sci-fi.
Driven by Stephen Curry's brilliant lead performance, this deeply moving story is told in an accessible but powerful manner.
With its strong narrative sense, unpretentious humour and amusing self awareness, Prince Of Persia: The Sands Of Time is ample proof that in Hollywood, a little care goes a long way.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Lincoln is a far more reckless, entertaining, unusual, but ultimately horribly uneven film than its pedigree may suggest.
Tarantino is starting to look more and more like an angry teenager in his bedroom going, "Wouldn't it be good if..."
A classy old school character drama that dips into sentimentality in its final stages, but remains first-rate in every other aspect.
Though hilariously funny and luridly hypnotic, God Bless America is quite possibly the angriest and saddest film of the last ten years.
A blisteringly original take on the American crime movie that's as thrilling as it is sobering.
This Prohibition-era crime drama boasts bravura performances, unforgettable characters, moments of shocking violence, and enough in-your-face entertainment for three films.
Matching its intelligent and taut thrills with richly developed characters and thought-provoking questions, this is one of the decade's best sci-fi flicks.
It may not be a slickly, richly cinematic experience, but it's something more important than that: funny.
Len Wiseman's remake of Paul Verhoeven's 1990 sci-fi cult classic is dull, repetitive and uninspired, despite a big budget and an attractive cast.
Fast paced, tightly plotted and strongly performed, The Bourne Legacy is an inventive continuation of the groundbreaking Bourne series.
Epic and exhilarating in its ambition and execution, Christopher Nolan delivers another landmark in comic book cinema and also a wholly satisfying end note for fans.
This smart, soulful and surprisingly darkly-hued comedy throws up a handful of interesting questions about personal responsibility.
It's a solid effort all round, but this really belongs to Ben Oxenbould whose brilliantly unhinged performance makes this a truly thrilling experience.
If you can get over the feeling that this is all very familiar, this superhero flick is a winner - nailing both the impressive action and the touching personal beats.
Everything about this film is tired and out of touch.
A disappointing, often repulsive and mean-spirited mess of a film with seemingly only one real criterion on its agenda: to shock and offend.
While Tim Burton disappointingly reins in the weirdness and struggles to nail the tone, this is still packed with memorable moments and terrific performances.
Announcing its debut director Kieran Darcy-Smith as a talent to watch, this superbly crafted tale always roots its thrills in rich characterisation.
Wildly entertaining yet brilliantly cohesive, wonderfully characterised, deftly humorous and packed with heart, this is an absolute winner.
Its two leads possess amusing chemistry but this smug and ultimately disappointing revamp never manages to strike the right note between action and comedy.
Despite occasional moments of silliness, the old-fashioned sense of adventure and brilliantly rendered aliens elevate this above other derivative big-budget sci-fi fare.
Entertaining, funny, occasionally poignant and always revealing, this is a warm and worthy celebration of a man often not given his due in country music.
With two compelling figures at its core, this engagingly honest and unapologetically positive doco makes for exciting and ultimately moving viewing.
The natural chemistry of the leads and frankly funny dialogue make for a delightful local gem.
Dotted with emotional honesty and strong storytelling that you only find in truly special movies.
One of this year's most original, entertaining and frankly shocking American movies.
An intelligent, emotionally driven ensemble film that we have come to expect from Soderbergh.
Firmly sticking to its noir roots, this is a modest but well-crafted achievement which remains entertaining throughout.
While its actions scenes are entertaining, the plot holes and open ending signal a lost opportunity for a potential franchise.

Filled with 'hilarious' scenes of people being vomited on and falling off roofs, Four Holidays tries to meld nasty, black-hued comedy with warm sentiment, resulting in a sick melange of treacle and malice.
Like its predecessor, Iron Man 2 is a fine example of how impressive big budget studio filmmaking can be when it's done right.
It's a testament to Christopher McQuarrie's cogent, keenly observed script and Singer's tightly controlled direction that the film remains so utterly compelling.
Like School Of Rock and The Bad News Bears, it cleverly walks a fine line by throwing kids in amongst the filth.
Perfectly captures the bittersweet moment when the once-free sport of surfing became the big money phenomenon that it is today.
Rich, ambitious and often brave, this is a film that reaches, with desperately clawing outstretched hands, for greatness.
While not for the cynical or hard-of-heart, Nights in Rodanthe is something of a rarity: a film that puts its characters first.
Despite the dog-eared set-ups and situations, Body of Lies also has a lot going for it.
Bitter & Twisted is a winning combination of glowing hope and battering despair.
A capable and highly watchable action adventure flick.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Taken is neither original nor meaningful...but that's not really the point, is it?

While the CGI battles between The Hulk and Abomination are expectedly clunky, there are enough fun references and strongly crafted scenes to mark The Incredible Hulk as a highly enjoyable, if not quite exceptional, comic book adaptation.
When it neglects the fizz in favour of the grit (or at least the kind of grit acceptable for Sex And The City), this femme phenomenon hits the spot.

Fun, entertaining, genuinely amusing, and made with an abundance of what appears to be honest-to-god warmth, Indiana Jones And The Kingdom Of The Crystal Skull is a worthy addition to one of the great movie franchises.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Shine A Light is pure rock'n'roll nirvana, standing mightily as one of the truly great concert films.
An exciting, funny, entertaining and utterly compelling piece of popcorn entertainment that sits at the top end of comic book adaptations.
As well as capturing the elusive glow of magic realism, Balsmeyer also succeeds in drawing fine performances out of his cast.
A striking, stately and ultimately deeply moving experience.
In trying to create an air of libertine cool, Proyas succeeds in looking like someone who's trying too hard.
'...beautifully captures the spirit and pace of a popular, bustling eating-house.'
'...a perfectly pitched blockbuster where the characters come first.'
This is the kind of subject matter that could so easily have been fumbled by a lesser filmmaker, but Ayres makes the right choices at every turn.
A wild ride juiced with enough energy and excitement for at least three films.
Roberts always grounds the film with the consistency of his characters and manages to punctuate proceedings with an 'Am I really seeing that?' moment about every 10 minutes.

With this film, Noyce has walked into the middle of the fray; using his gifts as a creator of expertly crafted, highly accomplished commercial successes, he has made a movie as exciting and accessible as it is timely.
The mix of slapstick and serious societal probing doesn't sit well.
Those who like their cinema on the edge should find a lot to enjoy here.
movie_title: He Died With A Felafel In His Hand (2001)

movie_review_blurb: A strong, consistently engrossing drama that boils with emotions distinctly real and recognizable.
It might be dressed up differently, but Monkey's is still a good, old-fashioned murder mystery.
Another deeply affecting and unforgettable film from a true American master.
This is an Oscar-calibre performance from Angelina Jolie. She conveys a sense of grief, desperation, fear, sadness and determination that is absolutely palpable.
While the jokes are admittedly very funny, they're constantly offset by a tumbling waterfall of schmaltz.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: More character piece than the expected tragedy or parody, W. is surprisingly good fun.
Gripping and thought provoking entertainment.
The real pity about the middle-of-the-road Hollywood comedy Date Night is that there's actually a great film in there somewhere kicking and clawing in a desperate effort to get out.

This idiotic "event movie" pretty much sums up everything that's wrong with Hollywood right now. It's big, it's loud, and it's filled with meaningless action...and it also feels like not one single person involved with the production could give two hoots.

Alice In Wonderland is most certainly a lot of fun, with flashes of comic spark and occasionally interesting visuals, but considering the array of talent on hand, this tea party has been seasoned with a little too much sugar, and not enough spice.
Although bogged down with its denouement, this is still Scorsese, which means genre cinema at its visionary best.
Deeply felt performances, great music and pitch-perfect detail make this a film to be cherished.
Eastwood seems to inherently know that even in a big story, it's the intimate moments that hold everything together, and he is never overwhelmed by the size of the story.

Though certainly not the pioneering experience it's been touted as, Avatar is an exciting, visually arresting, and occasionally powerful slab of Hollywood filmmaking driven by one of the industry's most committed, passionate, stand-alone creative forces.

The real beauty of Where The Wild Things Are comes with its simplicity. With only minimal plot to work with, Jonze instead makes this a weird, funky mood piece, finding an odd but highly effective rhythm on which the film joyously floats.
The first half is laboured and feels like a bridge for the third instalment, but there's still plenty of cast chemistry and great set pieces.
Ambitious, colourful and jolting film, which succeeds on the back of its winning performances and strain of magic realism.
A God-like experience for the rock music fan, this documentary contains both amazing music and insight.
A hard to fathom storyline and obvious CGI effects detract from an otherwise big-hearted final film for Heath Ledger.
Robin Hood is good rather than great, ultimately falling victim to its own self-seriousness despite flashes of genuine excitement.
Drew Barrymore's directorial debut is an absolute delight, with fast paced action, hilarious comedy and outstanding performances from the majority female cast.
Despite the sometimes crazy rhythm, the diverse and exuberant characters bring a sense of fun and merry frivolity to this one small tale about the iconic festival.
This rollicking epic harks back to typical wordy Tarantino fare, with the added explicit violence that's to be expected from this cult director.
An incredible film with a well crafted script, beautiful cinematography and a touching story that exposes a deep anger and sorrow.
Sacha Baron Cohen might be a one trick pony, but he sure knows how to give the audience, ahem, a good ride.
Director Harold Ramis knows enough about comedy to keep things ticking over nicely. That said, there's something undeniably lazy and tossed off about Year One: everyone feels like they're cruising.

Hilarious from go-to-whoa and visually compelling in its rarely seen Vegas-by-day aesthetic, The Hangover is the very definition of raucous entertainment, and will undoubtedly rate as one of the comedies of the year.
It's exciting and propulsive, but without the required core of emotion. That might not have seemed too important to the Terminator films, but once it's gone, you really notice.
It's a miracle! Angels & Demons is actually a well constructed, entertaining thriller.
Star Trek bristles with energy and excitement, and you can practically sense the enthusiasm with which this film has been approached by everyone involved.
Lacks any real sense of gravitas and intensity.
If you thought that Mickey Rourke had the market cornered on comebacks with his transcendent performance in Darren Aronofsky's masterpiece The Wrestler, then think again.
Digs enthusiastically into the rarely seriously discussed issue of the bond that can exist between man and machine.
A truly extraordinary achievement.
Comedy king Judd Apatow delivers another hit with this hilarious personal story that also deals with the big issues in a touching way.

The third installment in the game-changing Iron Man trilogy takes all the hard work done by Marvel Studios in creating a rich, thoughtful but never po-faced cinematic universe, and turns it into a big joke.
Sidestepping a more extreme take on prostitution, this is a quietly impressive portrait of a young woman caught in a tragic situation.
...the best kind of film: big enough to be bracing, but small enough to draw you right in, and then exercise a firm, vice-like grip.
...as a continuation of a truly superior action franchise, Jason Bourne is a rock-solid success...
Thought provoking and profoundly hilarious...
...a loving, affectionate, and wholly respectful new take on a much loved property...
...always entertaining and engaging...
...smart, funny, and visually astounding...
...a blockbuster with heart, soul, and brains.
...feels a little haphazard and undercooked...
...enjoyable but slightly underwhelming...
...a bright, vivid, compelling cocktail...
Bolstered by a voice cast on top form, and punctuated with moments of thrilling action, The Jungle Book is first class family entertainment from a burgeoning master of the medium.
It might come from a couple of newcomers, but Pawno is gloriously assured.
Kung Fu Panda 3 is no game-changer, but it's a solid entry into a consistently fun and funny animated franchise.

There's rarely been so much sub in the text of an animated movie, and while it makes Zootopia a surprisingly thought provoking experience, there's also something slightly disconcerting about Disney's willingness to so keenly embrace adult themes.
It's epic, involving, exciting, and ambitious, but there's an undeniable feeling that the best is yet to come.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It starts off as a taut, straight-from-the-headlines thriller, but eventually devolves into a giddy, cartoonish fantasy, where the world's complex problems can be solved with a punch to the face and a follow-up wisecrack.
Right from the get-go, Looking For Grace throws tonal consistency out the window, bouncing from broad comedy to serious drama at will, and not always seamlessly.
It might be an endurance test, but the rewards of The Revenant are plentiful.

Fresh, funny, and heartfelt, Sisters makes up for what it lacks in plot with a rolling succession of tear-inducing jokes and a gaggle of hard-partying characters that you would actually want to buy a drink for.

With its breakneck pacing; intelligent and measured reverence for the original films; punchy action sequences; and ambitious plotting, Star Wars: The Force Awakens is a near perfect continuation of the most beloved movie franchise of all time.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Devoid of special effects, but supercharged through the wit of its writing, the richness of its characterisation, and the evangelical profundity of its subtext, this film about one truly amazing woman rates as an eye-popping, breathtaking achievement.
Strong, unrelenting, moving and bracingly exciting, Revenge Of The Sith is a fitting end to a truly great series.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A rock-solid Bond flick that would have been hailed an immediate winner if it weren't for the fact that it has to shudder and shake in the darkness of the enormous shadow cast by its predecessor.
Entertaining and thought provoking, Bridge Of Spies gives real historical events a human face, and rates as a surprising crowd pleaser in the process.
To lazily but wholly appropriately use a very hoary old cliché, Pan is fun for the whole family.

Artfully shot by Simon Ford, with fine period detail from production designer, Josephine Ford, Cut Snake is technically top-notch, and emotionally uncompromising, as Ayres again strides into largely virgin territory for Australian cinema.
Oddball's brand of fun-with-heart will hopefully click with local kids and their parents too.
StalkHer is a nifty little black comedy bubbling and bristling with surprises and invention.
Impassioned and brave, Free State Of Jones is a towering piece of leftist American cinema...
The fact that Clint Eastwood continues to turn out such strong, impassioned, relevant, and entertaining work in his twilight years is nothing less than staggering.
...a lots-of-noise-and-action thigh-slapper for the kids...
...a straightforward tale of good guys and bad guys built on gunfights, machismo, and double barrelled toughness.
Predicting which Aussie films will swamp the box office is near impossible, but in terms of quality, this honest, heartfelt flick well and truly keeps its head above water.
Eric Clapton: Life In 12 Bars is a deeply personal, finely judged tour through the dark life of one of the world's greatest guitar players.
movie_title: Eric Clapton: A Life in 12 Bars (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "Though it doesn't dig deep, Notorious: Conor McGregor is exciting, energetic and occasionally revealing..."
Innuendo wears its influences proudly and with reckless abandon, but always functions as an engagingly original film in its own right.
A big, broiling stew of complex thought, Australia Day is a provocative, intelligent film that dares to pick, probe and ask a lot of burning questions.
A melancholy, heartfelt meditation on the complicated relationships that crafted The Go-Betweens, one of Australia's most eccentric and much-loved indie pop groups.

The story is nothing new and the performances are a little uneven, but the positivity of Rip Tide is contagious, while its standing as a modest piece of cinematic female empowerment (both in its narrative and off-screen creation) can't be understated.
Chilling and harrowing, Jungle soars in strange and unexpected ways.
Spider-Man: Homecoming is fresh, funny and entertaining, but it ultimately works better as a teen flick than it does as a superhero movie.
A vividly full-bodied, deeply moving, and wildly entertaining documentary about Radio Birdman, one of Australia's most seminal and enduring rock bands.
Whitney: Can I Be Me is a harrowing, uncompromising, beautifully crafted portrait of the deeply flawed pop princess.
"Though funny and pointed, War Machine is at its best when it drops the satire for more punchy drama."

This is no witch hunt: the filmmakers maintain an even handed tone throughout, and give equal time to all parties. It's ultimately Dyers and Hamilton who bring themselves undone, and Dyers' final outburst is highly unsettling and near-damning.
It could have used a dash of real, ragged rock'n'roll, but Ricki And The Flash remains a big hearted paean to those who live boldly and happily on the margins.
Despite feeling a little crime-film-familiar, Trespass Against Us triumphs through its towering performances and unusual setting.
In the great pantheon of rock docos, this is an instant classic.
Why Him? is the best Judd Apatow movie that Judd Apatow had nothing to do with: it's sweet, raunchy, big-hearted, and very, very funny.
...grabs you by the throat from its first frames and never lets you go.
Moana is Disney at its dreamy, catchy, heart-bursting best.
Fun, entertaining, gorgeously animated, and full of good tunes...
A classic boy-and-his-dog tale, Red Dog: True Blue has a big heart and bundles of charm...
...a wide-canvas drama literally bulging at the seams with big ideas...
...an impressive feature bold in its sense of ambition and rich with character-driven intimacy.
...rich with ideas and imagination...
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: ...there's something undeniably appealing and entertaining about this wholly ridiculous meld of bone-crunching action, off-the-wall characterisation, and hard won sentiment.
Itâ(TM)s exciting, entertaining, goofy, and fun...
After such a ham-fisted, disingenuous effort as Jack Reacher: Never Go Back, this potentially promising action franchise has taken one right between the eyes.
...a tough-minded, uncompromising film that unpicks the quiet horrors of suburban life...
This gay-themed Aussie coming of age drama goes straight to the top of the class.
There's a rawness, urgency, and intensity to Southpaw that is utterly invigorating, but there's also a rich beat of sensitivity that effectively counters its blood-specked rhythms.
This beautifully crafted drama richly personalises a man whose life story has so often been told in headlines and broad strokes.
Emotionally honest in an almost shocking way, and bulging with sexual and scatological humour, Trainwreck is also a deeply humanist and utterly affecting joy from start to finish.

Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes is a textbook example of how to get a blockbuster right: you can have all the mind-blowing action set pieces that you want, but they must be populated with characters that you actually care about.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: 5 Flights Up is one of those films that sneaks up on you.
Godzilla is just another big budget slab of sound-and-fury where things like characterisation, logic, and good storytelling get quickly and effectively trampled.
A satisfying follow-up to a film that cannily balanced its thrills-and-spills with teen angst, down-to-earth dramatic beats, and relatable family relationships.

Perfect paced, ingeniously scripted, and constantly compelling, Captain America: The Winter Soldier is, first and foremost, a top-tier thriller...which just happens to have a superhero in the middle of the action.

It's an often strange mix, but one that has an ultimately hypnotic quality, as Aronofsky digs not only into the richly freaky psychology of the tale, but also into its crammed hull of visual possibilities.

Out Of The Furnace is an all too rarely seen type of film: a big-feeling drama that proves that ambition doesn't have to be solely connected to the size of a film's budget and the number of special effects shots that it has.
Mclean remains true to genre expectations with Wolf Creek 2, though he departs from the norm by actually turning out a strong, bone-grinding follow up that doesn't smear the legend of the first film.
Layered with strongly crafted characters, and snaking thriller plot, the results are compelling, thought provoking, and highly entertaining.

The story of Nelson Mandela is a truly extraordinary one, and while Justin Chadwick's biopic never stoops to hagiography and always entertains, it sometimes feels like the weight of the narrative is too heavy for one movie.
Remake or not, Robocop's many, many problems are all brand new, and have little to do with the cruelty of comparison.
...an unhinged and highly quotable near-instant-classic, which constantly and ingeniously mines laughs from the most despicable and debauched behaviour imaginable
Though about one of the most undeniably commercial movie companies in history, there's something enjoyably strange about Saving Mr. Banks, and its gallery of unusual characters.
For fans of the series, and of the action genre in general, the big, bustling, wildly entertaining The Expendables 3 hits all the right notes...and it hits them very hard.
Director David O. Russell delivers once again with this wonderfully performed, wildly entertaining dissection of The American Dream.
Ridley Scott's latest film is occasionally a little too willfully obscure for its own good, but it still rates as a top-notch and highly original crime thriller.
Rush is Howard's most exciting, compelling, and utterly entertaining film in years, and feels like a movie made by a much, much younger filmmaker.
The brilliant Jeff Bridges is pretty much the whole show in this lazily enjoyable tale of afterlife cops doing battle with ghostly ghouls.

an acceptable sci-fi actioner, though after all this time, it ultimately rates as a safe return for the title character, rather than one that really grabs the audience by the throat and goes in for the kill.
In the end, Kick-Ass 2 just kicks the audience's arse too much, and with too much unnecessary force...
By mixing raunchy laughs with genuine warmth, this pot-dealing comedy sparks up as a gag-filled surprise about the need for familial connection.
In an ironic twist, this time it's the everyday that proves more involving and amusing than the film's shaky detour into the extraordinary.

At its best when keeping its action and characters grounded, this is a leaner, less-explosion-heavy comic book flick than most recent efforts, and thankfully absolves the sins of its much-maligned predecessor.
Pacific Rim proves that when the pilot of the film is a smart, switched-on filmmaker, even a loopy blockbuster about robots fighting monsters can have heart, brains and charm.
It's like Dumb & Dumber out on the range, but without the laughs.
Snyder largely succeeds in creating an epic piece of blockbuster filmmaking that still understands the value of smaller, intimate moments.

Sure, these films are hardly of the blue ribbon variety (and they don't pretend to be), but you actually do care about what is going to happen to the characters, which makes you gladly go along for the ride.
Breaking the mould is usually a brave and admirable cinematic act, but when it crashes the party here, it proves to be the ultimate big screen buzz-kill.
Francis Lawrence has crafted a gripping, richly textured sci-fi thriller with reams of underlying dystopian subtext.
Stylishly and crisply shot by Jason Thomas -- who reimagines Perth as a bleak, nighttime world of blurry lights and rolling freeways -- The Reckoning unfolds slowly but with great control.
Bold and ambitious, X-Men: Days Of Future Past is an admirably controlled thrill-ride tempered with perfectly shaded moments of arcing darkness.
Fun and fresh, Guardians Of The Galaxy is another winner from Marvel, and further proof of a very old dictum: you've got to gamble big to win big.
Fantastic Four feels like a film with nobody at the wheel, as it careens around shambolically before grinding to a slamming halt as the creative fuel runs dry.
The Simpsons Movie successfully makes a big experience of one of the greatest TV shows of all time.

Nolan makes his far-fetched (and even occasionally ridiculous) dialogue and plotting utterly, absolutely believable within the film's finely structured framework, while never losing his grip on the dense, multi-layered narrative.
As with all of Marvel Studios' movies, the action, humour and innate silliness is tempered with something a little more thoughtful and meditative, making for a highly entertaining mix.
Joe Johnston hits just the right tone, finding the heart of this often misunderstood character, and tempering proceedings with the perfect blend of humour, action and characterisation.

Thor: The Dark World is a wildly entertaining continuation of Marvel's dominance of the big budget action blockbuster genre, and a savvy revisit of its most difficult and ambitious piece of character mythology.
...it somehow lovingly homages a great film while pissing all over it at the same time.
[Ted 2] proves that Seth MacFarlane is much, much more than just a filmmaker aiming for cheap, easy giggles.
The Bourne Ultimatum is a fitting end to one of the finest blockbuster franchises of recent years.

While it might not feel as complete and well-rounded as the first movie, Sin City: A Dame To Kill For is a worthily prurient follow-up that offers up a whole bundle of new cinematic tricks, and a rogue's gallery of exciting new characters.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This action pioneer throws down the gauntlet to his much younger peers, and lets them know that when it comes to crunching metal, shredded tyres, terrifying villains, and flawed anti-heroes, he is the king.
It's an extraordinary cinematic portrait of a deeply complex man.
A film of big ideas and rich themes that nevertheless grabs you by the throat and doesn't let go until the credits have rolled.
Avengers: Age Of Ultron is a big, bold, funny, thrilling, absorbing triumph, and continues Marvel Studios' seeming push for world cinematic domination.

Jurassic World is so seamless and spot-on that it's difficult to fathom why it has taken Steven Spielberg and backing studio, Universal, so long to come up with a continuation of one of their biggest franchises.
Though many scratched their heads when Aussie filmmaker, James Wan, was tapped to replace the departing Justin Lin in the director's chair, he proves to be a perfect fit.
Fun? Hardly. Forgettable? Absolutely not.
Unpredictable, richly crafted, and beautifully written, The Drop is like the best liquor from the top shelf: it goes down hard and harsh, but it hangs on and gets its hooks right into you.
...a thoughtful, provocative thriller replete with richly crafted characters, gripping set pieces, and an underlying moral drive about the very nature and consequences of violence.
Cheap and fun, Turkey Shoot is an entertaining slab of nouveau Ozploitation.
A big film with a big heart, Unbroken is a deeply moving masterclass on resilience, self-belief, and fighting rebel spirit.
Bravely refusing any form of hagiography, Eastwood triumphs with a measured, morally complex, and utterly gripping snapshot of what war can do to the men who fight it.
In this third installment, it's the audience that gets taken...for its time, money, and intelligence.
You can literally feel the sloppy, all-encompassing and not always rational love that its creators have for the material, and their desire to offer up something new is deeply engaging.

Beautifully adapted from the stories of boxing expert F. X. Toole, Million Dollar Baby initially looks like a classic sports-movie-rags-to-riches deal, but it's when Eastwood digs deeper that the film really takes flight.
Manny Lewis is a bittersweet, utterly charming romantic comedy, and Carl Barron is a delight.
If you're looking for the top big screen debuts of the year, you'll find two straight off the bat in the nail-grinding thriller, '71.
The Homesman is a strange, challenging western that confounds expectations at every turn.
Admirably daring and filled with wonderfully vivid performances, Birdman also feels at times more like an exercise in style than a genuine emotional experience.
Lighthearted and often funny.
A surprisingly thoughtful social film.
The whole mess boils down to a transparently hypocritical work that feels as though it's trying to set the women's liberation movement back 20 years.
movie_title: Amy's O (Amy's Orgasm) (Why Love Doesn't Work) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: From complete dismemberment to extreme shotgun violence, Aja & Co. not only pull out the stops on this one, they decimate them.

A charming and funny look at the independent filmmaking business and the thin line between a masterpiece and a $9 nap.

A thoughtful, moving piece that faces difficult issues with honesty and beauty.
Despite the rambling finish, however, overall the film is a thought-provoking and graceful portrait of a tenacious peace warrior whose frankness is his greatest weapon.
While the film at times feels like a clumsily acted play, a surprising turn by Delta Burke carries the cast out of the doldrums of an often-strained plot line.
Despite the lack of an especially defined narrative arc, the people are what make the movie -- as they should in a tale like this.

Director Juan Carlos Fresnadillo re-creates the gritty and spastic look of Days while brilliantly utilizing dark space and shadow to enhance the terror.

It's all so much more fun when you're the one with the controller, telling the heroes what to do: Watching this stuff unfold onscreen is like sitting by while someone plays your video games without you.
Sea Monsters will undoubtedly bring open-mouthed awe and joy to brainy kids from ages 8 to 108.
It wants to answer the questions it's clearly too timid to ask, but the questions are always so much more interesting.
... succeeds as a modest tribute to the kind of aging boys club that idles for hours in somebody's parents' rumpus room, its members tossing around big-man talk but trapped in emotional adolescence.
There are only so many story threads an ensemble cast can hold.

Feardotcom is full of inconsistencies and contradictions, but none are more disturbing than the fact that not a single policeman wears gloves at any of the umpteen crime scenes scattered throughout the film.

[Dory's] throwaway lines are funnier than anything that comes out of all the other fish combined, balancing out the dull father-son-must-be-reunited story at the core of Nemo that threatens to make this just another cartoon.
Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers is a pitch-perfect second act, full of dark wonder and the slow, pounding pulse of Aragorn's unflagging hope.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: I could almost recommend Return to Me to the more saccharine of my acquaintances were it not for a sugary denouement.
A takeoff on Douglas Sirk's overwrought, color-saturated 1950s melodramas that rises above its camp roots and converts artifice into art.
My Boss's Daughter is a stinker from start to endless finish.
A dubious proposition for the Francophobic, but it acquits itself with a script so ridiculous that it can't help but be engaging.
[A] predictable and sugarcoated (even criminally negligent) take on The Parent Trap.
Quote not available.
An engrossing study of race and history in Australia.

There's not a single surprise or moment of dramatic tension.

It all collapses under an atrocious performance by Pacino.

movie_review_blurb: Writer-director Dan Harris attempts a juggling act of tone, style and genre that results in about half a dozen different movies being shuffled across the screen, none of which -- despite fine performances all around -- really works.
The film succeeds again and again at pulling you to the edge of your seat and keeping you there.
Hooks viewers by having us ride shotgun to Paul's awakening consciousness.
While the acting is top-notch, the real star of the film is the script.
A diabolically enjoyable documentary on unearned self-esteem.
A wonderful, wistful twist on Rear Window.
movie_title: The Other Side of the Street (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Albaladejo turns his film into a banal, mildly entertaining trifle of affirmation, eliciting a shrug more than any real emotion.

Opening with a portentous quote from Kafka, writer-director Ari Kirschenbuam's Fabled quickly reveals itself to be a hyper-stylized flick, but the glossy sum effect is that of a film student straining for a weightiness he can't pull off.
Lough doesn't bomb the system; he sucks it off.
A determinedly old-fashioned boxing/ coming-of -age film, only perfunctorily hitting its marks.
A former short film stretched beyond the interest of its wanly amusing riffs, it settles for easy, familiar jokes and slack storyline tension.
Its lackluster efforts to be raunchily topical about issues of race, class and sexuality leave its talented cast stranded without a paddle.
It's when adults with whitewashed notions of childhood get hold of a camera that kiddie fare -- like this uninspired effort from writer-director Eric Hendershoot -- goes limp.
This film puts a pained human face on the cost of the corporate status quo.
An enjoyable ride.
This look at the assorted struggles of modern hetero coupledom gives off a distinctly moldy aroma.
Those who are already in her camp will find much to feed on in this at once intellectualized and accessible, documentary-style peek inside the head of a passionately driven woman and artist.

The drama is unintentionally humorous, the humor incredibly labored and the acting rarely better than one might find in a Chi Chi LaRue XXX production.
LaChapelle wisely avoids too much MTV-style quick-editing and camera trickery, letting the kids dazzle on the strength of their talent.
More predictable than its makers seem aware, its emotional hooks much too dull to pull us in.
This concert film of her most recent comedy tour, the Assassin Show, is painfully bereft of wit or cogent insight.
Though sprung from the mind of a woman, the film plays like a hetero male fantasy of tortured love.

While the documentary footage ... is powerful, it's often undermined by the fact that you know there is deep contrivance at work.
An intellectually steelier case against Bush, his cabalistic administration and the Iraq war than Michael Moore's Fahrenheit 9/11.
The film doesn't negate or sidestep the land mines of modern teen life and parenting, but it often veers into Reefer Madness cautionary territory.

The sexual arena is where all sorts of issues get worked out, sure, but, sexuality is far more nuanced and complicated than can be contained in a few identity boxes or capsulized by physical practices.
If Civil Brand works ... as an updated women's prison melodrama with a strong whisper of political consciousness, there are some crippling flaws in the film.

Green and Siegel have done an extraordinary job of bottling a pivotal moment in American history -- the feel and the frenzy of it -- then uncorking it so that the audience experiences both the rush and the horror of violent political action.

The score, costumes, sets and intentionally bad, exposition-heavy dialogue (delivered in either cool deadpan or borderline-hysterical readings) are a deft mix of campy spoof and finely shaded replication.

Directors Fenton Bailey and Randy Barbato (who also directed the marginally better 1998 documentary of the same name, on the same subject) are too enamored of the tawdry tale to actually say anything with or about it.
The movie is stolen by the gorgeous, droll and hilarious Depp. The movie crackles when he's onscreen and only fitfully sparks when he's not.

movie_review_blurb: [Garrity's] story nor his etch-a-sketch, cliche-addled characters ever take flight.
Old news for anyone who has seen even one or two documentaries on similar subject matter.
Witty, surprisingly tender.
Tough and relentless, dazzlingly researched and crafted.
Unfortunately, Baur doesn't seem to have either a thesis or an editor as she lets each segment meander without purpose.
A charming, illuminating portrait of the complex and storied queer romance between Isherwood and Bachardy.
So riddled with limp clichés that it doesn't even qualify as a guilty pleasure.
Even ignoring the low-grade aesthetics, the documentary feels like you've stepped into a geek-nerd convention where all but hardcore initiates will be either bored or amused by the proceedings.
movie_title: Carlos Castaneda: Enigma of a Sorcerer (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Short on charm, purpose or laughs.
The filmmakers deftly capture the boys' depression and triumphs, but something of the American character -- the generosity and the arrogance -- as well.
As written by Geoffrey Saville-Read and directed by Sven Pape, the satire is toothless.

Pushing creepiness into horror -- and giving the movie its sting -- are the recollections and insights of folks who've tracked the handiwork of Rove, this summer's scariest movie monster, for more than 30 years.
Both the people and the plot become so riddled with illogic and inconsistency that you don't care -- or fully buy it -- when an explanation, of sorts, gels in the end.
For all the violence and breaking-up- to-make-up that go on, there's never really a sense of risk or exploration, and the film's pulse never rises above faint.
Squanders Mac's natural gift of salty gruffness by shoehorning him into a dull, heartwarming cinematic lesson on humility and the joys of teamwork.
At once a woefully overfamiliar bashing of Hollywood superficiality and a seemingly unwitting paean to the self-absorbed enlightenment that passes among industry folk for personal growth.
The relentless hagiography by Salles and screenwriter Jose Rivera results in a bloodless exercise.
The script, by David T. Wagner and Brent Goldberg, is breathtakingly bad.
The biggest surprise (and asset) here is Pegg, who imbues the slightly daft Shaun with a good nature and bigger heart, providing the film with a central figure you actually care about.

movie_title: Going Upriver: The Long War of John Kerry (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Timoner doesn't intrude on the events being filmed or impose editorial comment on what the audience is watching, and there's no need to.
What really sink the film are the script's reductive, outdated psychological implications ... and its clumsy melodramatics.
Loaded with fantastic old footage and photographs of the Vietnam War, of the American civil rights movement and of Zinn's own family.
movie_title: Howard Zinn: You Can't Be Neutral on a Moving Train (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Though the film covers familiar queer-cinema ground, Latter Days' finely observed truths about the painful costs of being yourself make even the contrivance of its happy ending forgivable.
Make It Funky! is in many respects a stock item, but what gives the film newfound ache is the copious amount of time it spends on the streets with ordinary citizens.
It's a full-throttle assault on sacred cows and social propriety, issued from a slyly molded persona of white-girl privilege and cocksure ignorance.
It's to be hoped that by his next film, his director's gift won't be shortchanged by the writer in him mistaking psychological complexity for acting-school exercises.
Shottas, based on a true story, has been sitting on shelves for a few years now, accruing mythology as a great film that's been unjustly sidelined. That, it is not. [It's] wretched.
Takes a hot-button issue (here, it's homophobic U.S. immigration policies) and reduces it to dry sloganeering and shameless emotional manipulation of the audience.
What pulls the viewer in (aside from the charismatic real-life family playing the roles) is the film's compassionate, empathetic perspective.
movie_title: The Cave of the Yellow Dog (Die Hohle des gelben Hundes) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Neither Biraben's script nor his direction leave room for doubt as to how he feels about the nightmarish past, but he's smart enough to know that even justified outrage sometimes has to be tempered with the complexities of human intentions and realities.
Where Snow Blind dazzles is in its generous serving of performance footage: Watching the devoted soar through the air, flipping and spinning with near-balletic skill, takes your breath away.
Shot on digital and layered with animated segments, performance footage and clips from Smith family home movies, Family Movie unfolds with a gentle, justified confidence in the power of its subject.

A film made by people just smart enough to acknowledge that the tropes of modern queer filmmaking have been reduced to cliché, but who themselves lack the courage to push beyond tried-and-true box-office formulas.
It's gross-out fare of the highest caliber.
Rock the Bells [ends] on a high note, but in a minor chord of sadness.
A sobering, engrossing film that raises a red flag on a criminal class that is being created for corporate profit.
A well-acted trifle straining to be a hard-hitting morality play.

U2, notoriously tight with the rights to their music and image, were reportedly so impressed by the script that they allowed their music and some concert footage to be used for very cheap. They got gypped.
The acting is fine enough to slowly pull the viewer in, making you care just a bit how it all turns out.
Dead One never generates either the fear or just tension that it intends with its portentous music, religious iconography and meant-to-be-creepy voice-overs.
The cast comprises some of the most beautiful people on Earth. In fact, the chance to see the still impossibly sexy [Sonia] Braga in action almost makes the whole exercise worthwhile.
Writer-director Jamie Babbit's follow-up to But I'm a Cheerleader, while flawed and in need of at least one more script overhaul, is smarter, funnier and more accomplished than its predecessor.

Few of the songs, which range from gleefully raunchy to gratingly sentimental, are truly memorable.
The breezy tone and obvious fun being had by the cast make Finishing the Game a slight, low-key cool cinematic essay on identity politics.
The Caltech Beavers are a surprisingly charming group of overachievers who prove to have as much heart on the court as they do brains in the classroom.
A beguiling comedy from a Marxist-inflected thesis that is filled with characters who rage against the machine with pessimism, optimism, and navet (C)"sometimes in rotation.
What you ultimately take from the film is the awareness that this smart, self-aware, uncensored kid has been playing to a camera in his own head since well before Venditti came along.
It's a wit-free homage to Hitchcock and M. Night Shyamalan that, for all its slick presentation, never comes close to hitting the mark of its forebears.
Where writer-director Bethany Ashton really excels is in capturing the complex dynamics of small-town life.
Walsh nearly redeems the whole thing: His eyes flicker with an intelligence that isn't in the script, and he graces his character with layers of inner life in a film that coasts on surfaces.
Never delivers either the thrill of its underworld setting or much insight into its complicated workings.
The audience is herded from cliché to unintentional farce to insult-to-its-intelligence.
Director Michael Skolnik's generically crafted documentary on the precarious conditions of Swaziland, last functioning monarchy in Africa, is a curious mixture of banality and revelation.
The real rewards of this tough-minded yet hugely enjoyable throwback to earlier queer and art-house cinema work are its psychologically complex characterizations and its gorgeous craftsmanship.
In showing all the stuff that the History Channel discreetly edits out, Excellent Cadavers dismantles the celluloid romanticizing of the Mafia.
An often infuriating (and excruciating) film to watch, but one that gets to the root of the despair that now plagues so much of the African continent.
One of those all-too-rare films that handle preadolescent queerness with intelligence and unflinching honesty.
[MacDonald's] subjects -- former black chorus girls from Harlem's golden age, when the Cotton Club and the Apollo Theater ruled New York nightlife -- are utterly captivating.

It's not really original stuff, and there are few genuine surprises, but Painter skillfully layers visual details and off-the-cuff dialogue into a smart, condescension-free piece on small towns and the complicated lives they contain.
[The film] is most successful if viewed as a glossy video-log of a men's trendy lifestyle photo shoot.
Though the film is crammed with music -- the soundtrack is stellar -- the production numbers fall completely flat, leaving you to pine for the over-caffeinated touch of Baz Luhrmann.
A wise and moving coming-of-age tale.
A palpably heartfelt final scene between Dorian and his mom ends the tale on a powerful note.
Try though Greenwald might to not end things on a defeatist note, one observation from early in the film lingers: What Wal-Mart obliterates in small communities can never be replaced or regained.
movie_title: Wal-Mart: The High Cost of Low Price (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The film is packed with fantastic archival footage.

It's all very moving and uplifting. It's also exasperating.
Well-meaning but mediocre.
In unflinching terms, it captures the hellish existence endured by the many so that the few may wallow in privilege.
Block Party puts Chappelle (who co-produced the movie) in the host position, and he's very funny...

Yet for all of its retro charm, the movie is ultimately too routine to recommend.
The skating routines are a lot of fun to watch, filled with great choreography and backed by great tunes.

It may not be, as the title says, the greatest game every played, but it certainly is a darn good round of golf.
The magic just isn't there.
Heavy on style and atmosphere and light on virtually everything else.
A pale remake of a 25-year-old horror film that wasn't all that memorable to begin with.
Robert Zimmerman achieved his dream of becoming a singer, but in doing so he surrendered the ability to define himself on his own terms.
Taken as a whole, this is a superb film and an astonishing technical achievement.

movie_review_blurb: Works as a piece of blockbuster entertainment.
