Quote not available.
A relentlessly paced but almost comically nonsensical big-screen version of a TV series that's remembered more for its nostalgic value than its actual quality.
It's refreshing to see a movie like Slither, which has obviously been made by someone with a deep affection for the glory gory days of American horror comedy.
An insightful and moving documentary.
Accomplishes the impressive task of vanishing completely from your mind as you're sitting in the theater watching it.
The writer/director stifles any actual feeling with thudding, heavily-underlined subtext-as-text dialogue and an overreliance on indie rock scored musical montages
Soloway isn't so much interested in the reality of the movie's underlying scenario as she is the all-too-real emotional hurricane it stirs up.
Too predictable for adults and too saccharine for even very young kids, this family-oriented comedy is strictly dullsville.
This hybrid of a character study and a true-crime account is well-acted and suitably tense, but lacks a deeper resonance.

Not fast enough to be farce, not twisted enough to be dark comedy and not over-the-top enough to be a gonzo action comedy, the movie spins its chamber around and around for almost two hours, firing blank after blank.
I'm not sure that Riddick is an effective argument in favor of continuing Riddick's solo adventures, but it's a more fitting conclusion to his chronicles than the previous movie.
When it's Eva and Albert sharing the screen, getting to know each other and falling in love, Enough Said is genuinely delightful.
Bana and Hall seem as bored with the proceedings as the audience.
Armed with a solid script and two great actors, Howard's chief contribution is keeping the movie clipping along.
Seven decades on, it's still wholly transporting, even without the benefit of the bells and whistles that are part of the CGI age.
Why make an average concert movie when you can make something as weirdly mesmerizing as Through the Never?
Before it flies off the rails in the final act, Joseph Gordon-Levitt's first self-penned, self-directed star vehicle, Don Jon, is an uncommonly provocative spin on familiar rom-com tropes.
There's also little insight to be gleaned from this stolid docudrama.
The movie toggles unconvincingly between grounded emotions and sitcom shtick.
When it simply sticks to the facts of the tragedy, The Summit is gripping stuff.
So many effects-heavy films promise to show you something you've never seen before. Gravity delivers.
If you're looking for a filmed Romeo to get your kids acquainted with one of Shakespeare's most easily-digestible plays, this is a perfectly fine (if not entirely authentic) choice.
When you finally emerge from your two-and-a-half hour sentence watching this glum, overbearing movie, you'll relish the sweet taste of freedom, too.
A rollicking entertainment, boasting some terrific (and terrifically unexpected) plot twists, a bunch of laugh-out-loud gags and clever action set-pieces.
By no means a revolutionary film, but it is an evolutionary one for its maker.
A rewarding experience, even if it fails to completely sweep you off your feet.
I'm So Excited has more than enough characters and storylines to fill its confined space. What the movie lacks, however, are belly laughs, hearty guffaws or even mild chuckles.
With the ostensible hero a maroon and the plot a draggy mess, the movie is essentially counting on Depp's broad comic theatrics to carry the day.
The Way, Way Back only really gets interesting when Carell enters the frame and introduces an unconventional villain into this entirely too-conventional coming-of-age scenario.
Perfectly adequate airplane reading.
The Look of Love is the latest and -- I'm sorry to report -- the least of Coogan and Winterbottom's team-ups.
In a summer that's been dominated by spectacles that feel small and self-contained despite the enormous wads of cash thrown at the screen, this is the first movie to come along that thinks big.
A noble effort to contextualize the life of a man who would become famous for the way that he died.
It's an effectively made (if still overlong) film, one that elevates a single athlete's story into legend as a way into his country's history. Just don't confuse this particular legend for fact.
An extremely well-crafted piece of mainstream horror that offers a number of genuine scares.
I can only hope that Gosling and Refn had a grand old time making Only God Forgives, because watching it sure is a bore.
Even though it's an improvement over the first RED, the film as a whole is just as disposable.
Wiig's shtick-heavy performance is just the tip of the iceberg when it comes to the problems afflicting this dire "comedy."

The Wolverine is good enough that I kept wishing it were better -- that there was another layer to the story or another wrinkle to a character's motivation or a truly spectacular set-piece that lent the proceedings some extra oomph.
Even when the jokes don't land, the sheer likability of the cast keeps the audience engaged.
If you want to see what capital-A Acting looks like, take a gander at Cate Blanchett in Woody Allen's latest feature.
We're pretty sure this is the last we'll ever see of the new Munster clan.
What's missing from The Butler aren't good performance, solid production values and an obvious respect for history -- it's the ability to make that history seem vital, to make it matter.
The first Kick-Ass wasn't a great movie, but it did have two great jokes driving it. With Kick-Ass 2, the joke is entirely on the audience.
One heck of a generic genre piece.
movie_title: The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Grindhouse and Machete were satires of exploitation films -- Machete Kills is simple exploitation -- both of the cast and the audience's goodwill.
The revamped vampire mythology put forth in Byzantium is much more fascinating than the actual story the movie sets out to tell.
It all pays off in a truly powerful closing scene that features some of the best screen acting Hanks has ever done.
Though an evocative portrait of a particular place, Juan Manuel Echavarría's slender documentary never feels as though it's telling the whole story.
Vaughn stumbles through the movie looking perpetually annoyed, as if he's just been woken up from a nap.

As if we needed one, Philomena gives us all yet another reason to praise Judi Dench, the Grand Dame of contemporary British cinema and an actress capable of elevating even the most predictable material.
A spirited romp through a traditional Disney princess narrative that ultimately tweaks the formula in ways that make it exciting and new.
It's in moments like that that Black Nativity really sings; the rest of the time it operates at a familiar hum.
If somebody had to remake Oldboy, I'm glad it was Spike Lee.

It's the most incongruous (and enjoyably so) good guy/bad guy pairing since Philip Seymour Hoffman threatened to make Tom Cruise's girlfriend bleed and cry and call out his name in Mission: Impossible III.
There's ultimately too much chaos and not enough control in Chadwick's presentation of Mandela's decades-spanning history.
Yet another home run for a pair of filmmakers who have proven incapable of striking a false note for four movies now.
This new creative team doesn't just repeat the previous film or the book... they substantially improve upon both.
A movie that sets out to be the antidote to glossy revenge pictures, but becomes that very thing.
Nuclear Nation's anti-nuclear stance is very clear, but it admirably wants viewers to understand its argument instead of shouting it at them.

In its reliance on sloganeering in place of substantive debate, The Unbelievers winds up being almost as insular as any dogmatic religious group. Instead of opening viewers' minds, it's just preaching to the choir.
As a Middle-earth softie, The Desolation of Smaug mostly provides what I've been hoping to get out of Jackson's second tour-of-duty in Tolkien land.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It's a messy movie, yes, but that complements the messy personalities at its center.
As much as the script strains to connect Travers' past with her present, Saving Mr. Banks instead resembles two very different movies shoved together.
Seeing The Sound of Music on DVD minus the live element (and its driving, hate watch-fueled Twitter traffic) makes it seem like an even bigger mess.
Flabby though it may be at times, this sequel delivers a steady stream of laughs and, more importantly, doesn't diminish our goodwill for this bunch of idiots.
I really can't say enough about how vividly the filmmaker and his creative team render this World of Tomorrow.
It's a film about the process of creativity, one that shows just how closely art and science are often intertwined.

Having picked such an intriguing environment to depict onscreen, it's more than a little disappointing that Nashef then settles for such a routine storyline, one that's flatly told and not all that funny to boot.
A deceptively low-key road movie that carries some real comedic and dramatic bite.
If The Wind Rises doesn't soar to the heights of the director's finest works, it is a deeply felt and visually ravishing goodbye from one of the undisputed masters of modern animation.
A Vegas-set dramedy that begins as a spikey comedy only to evolve into precisely the kind of banal, self-improvement seminar that one of Cody's edgy heroines would snark endlessly through.
In his typically visceral way, McQueen rips the scab off a wound that may never fully heal and dares us to look away.
Condon doesn't trust the story -- or history itself -- to be interesting enough on its own terms.
I was completely absorbed throughout All is Lost and appreciated the skill with which Chandor brought his very specific vision to life.
This interpretation does a nice job exploring the moral complexity of King's revenge premise... at least until Carrie is required by the plot to unleash hell.
Despite solid performances and handsome production values, Kill Your Darlings ends up feeling like a 100-minute preamble to the real story of the Beat Generation.
A rushed, chaotic and almost incoherent recap of the backstory behind the Lower East Side's iconic (and now defunct) punk music club.
All but certain to irritate general audiences and crater at the box office, The Counselor is nevertheless perversely fascinating -- half misfire and half inspired.
An absorbing, relatable story that also achieves an intimacy and raw emotional power.
Suffers from the same too-muchness of Love Actually and almost-instantaneous forgettability of Pirate Radio.
Even the committed efforts of these veteran actors can't completely distract from the movie's reliance on hoary clichés and predictable jokes.
McConaughey delivers a fine performance in Dallas Buyers Club, but it's less impressive when you realize that the entire movie has been rigged in his favor.
In its best moments, the film offers the mix of impressive spectacle and resonant substance that you always hope for when headed into the latest sci-fi blockbuster.

Because HBO will basically let him do whatever he wants, Larry David passed up making another season of Curb Your Enthusiasm to instead write and star in this semi-improvised feature that has an A-list cast and C-list material.
Andrew Cohn and Davy Rothbart's debut documentary feature is an evocative portrait of a small town in crisis. Too bad the basketball stuff keeps getting in the way.
It's a good thing that Taylor and the cast have such a firm grasp on the mirco details, because on a macro-level, The Dark World just barely hangs together.
It's all a little overwrought to be honest, with Macdonald unable to effectively modulate the movie's mood swings.
A smart, involving movie that effectively tackles real-world issues within the context of a well-plotted narrative.
The running time may be intimidating, but At Berkeley absolutely belongs on the short list of the year's finest documentaries.
The fact that it was shot on location is the most interesting thing about this curiosity, which otherwise isn't inventive or innovative enough to enter the canon of the truly great cult classics.
At three hours long, The Wolf of Wall Street also stands as a monument to the characters' flair for excess.
White House Down is as much a comic book fantasy as something like The Avengers.
A Hijacking accomplishes a tricky task, generating tension through talk rather than action.
That this utterly disposable, entirely generic piece of action movie mayhem is allowed to advertise itself under the Die Hard banner is a travesty.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The movie version completely drains the narrative of whatever charm or intrigue might have existed on the page, leaving behind a dry, withered husk.
Unable to fall back on his default strongman setting, Johnson is more human than we've seen him before.

Thanks to Park's endless creativity behind the camera, it's impossible to look away from Stoker, even when what's happening on the screen is truly risible.
This is, at heart, a melodrama cloaked in action movie clothing.
Taken purely on its own terms, Oz the Great and Powerful is a serviceable family blockbuster.
The Girl is still more "good for you" than "good," but at least it supplements its feature-length lecture with a pair of good performances and a decent payoff.

Save for one genuinely exciting stretch that begins roughly a half-hour in, the bulk of the film is dull and derivative.
A highly stylized art film that brutally (and, at times, brilliantly) sends up a society and (pop) culture that enables and enhances all the things it claims to bemoan.
I'm not quite sure why Stewart felt compelled to make this movie, but to her credit I guess, she commits to the story she's telling, as lurid, unpleasant and ultimately pointless as it may be.
Even if the movie itself isn't any fun, spotting all of its blatant mistakes and Ed Wood-ian budgetary shortfalls definitely is.
It's mostly harmless, but also pretty lifeless.

Even when Burns's script falters, Soderbergh's direction remains laser-precise.

Not since Pacino squared off against Robert De Niro in Righteous Kill has a single movie so thoroughly blasphemed a set of Acting Gods.
There's a high degree of insularity to the world Apatow presents onscreen.

[The film] often feels stuck in second gear dramatically, remaining watchable without ever becoming truly compelling.

Damon and Krasinski have the makings of a decent writing team, but their next script would benefit from a few more revisions.
A worthwhile appendix to the West Memphis Three case.
The film's power stems from the way Haneke avoids milking the viewer's sympathy.
If 56 Up is something of a pleasant bore while you're watching it, it gains more resonance when you think about it as the calm before the approaching storm.
An intriguing depiction of urban gentrification in action, marred somewhat by an unnecessary dip into the first person.
The movie doesn't much build to a climax as accidentally stumble upon it on the way to the closing credits.

Quartet is ultimately too thinly conceived, lacking a compelling dramatic throughline.

A solid, if unexceptional, urban crime yarn.
While Jee-woon has displayed a great deal of visual flair in his South Korean features, his work here proves disappointingly straightforward and impersonal.
Statham allows himself to be goofy on occasion as well, which is why this ranks as one of his most enjoyable performances to date.
Not only did Warm Bodies fail to convince me of its central conceit, but the movie's general depiction of zombie life is shoddy, inconsistent and often downright dumb.
Overall, Blancanievesis a minor achievement in the annals of Snow White re-tellings, but not an insignificant one.
The Heat may be more of the same buddy cop stuff, but the stars lend it extra punch where it counts.
Make no mistake, The Host is a bad movie, but it's the kind of bad movie that's almost compulsively watchable if only to see how much worse it could possibly get.
No one saw Raimi's Evil Dead coming three decades ago and were unprepared for what it had to offer. This Evil Dead delivers what you expect... and it's the weaker for it.
The Fast and the Furious franchise's gradual transformation from action movie serial to full-blown TV soap opera (with occasional car chases) is at last complete.
Compared to the wackadoo ramblings of The Happening or the stark-raving silliness of Lady in the Water, this film is a more generic failure.

The movie is sure-footed in its storytelling, right up to its appropriately open-ended conclusion.
The premise is the only interesting thing about The Purge, which very quickly devolves into a poorly-staged, narratively-challenged home invasion picture.
Rapture-Palooza assembles a reliable cast of comics and then proceeds to saddle them with truly middling material.
Clever for a little while, but turns irritating halfway through.
A modest pleasure that greatly benefits from Weixler's charismatic presence.

No matter how long the gap between movies has been or how completely the characters' lives have changed, when Jesse and Celine turn to each other and start one of their famously epic conversations, it feels like no time has passed at all.
It's a 50/50 split as two of the shorts are great and two... well, not so much.
It's a delight for Whedonites, but -- I'm sorry to say -- a rather mediocre production of Shakespeare.
[It's] more interested in making you smile than making you think. And it mostly accomplishes that modest goal, thanks to the witty music and charmingly low-fi production values.
I had a grand old time at this apocalypse, where 75-80% of the jokes land and the cast's eager-to-please energy, mostly carry you through the gags that fall short.
This is the first time where the director has allowed herself to be so openly contemptuous of the people in her own movie and that judgmental air suffocates The Bling Ring.
Man of Steel keeps Superman -- and the aspirational spirit he represents -- grounded and it's a less heroic movie for it.
World War Z may be a Frankenstein's monster of a movie, but it crackles with just enough electricity to keep the story moving forward and take the audience along for the ride.

Should Wood decide to indulge his manic side again, here's hoping he picks a better vehicle than Maniac.
Tiger Eyes retains some of the seriousness and respect for character that distinguishes Blume's YA books. What it lacks, however, is her strong authorial voice.
Turning this installment into The Hangover III: The Search for Chow illustrates how starved for ideas the filmmakers are.

As you can probably tell, I found the message behind Phil Spector pretty laughable. As drama, it's not particularly convincing either, even with Mamet's rat-a-tat-tat flair for dialogue mostly intact.
McGehee and Siegel -- as well as the adult cast -- are to be commended for keeping the film's depiction of marital strife from falling into melodrama and goopy sentimentality.

A small-scale, working-class character study that's never quite as nuanced and dramatic as it aspires to be.
[It] takes a crucial piece of sports and social history and treats it with kid gloves, substituting Hollywood gloss for real-world grit.
You already have to be a fan of Malick to want to look past the movie's somewhat bland surface. But if you do, you might experience some of the wonder promised by the title.

As a director, Kosinski is a great production designer. But as a dramatist? Not so much.
Cusack's glum visage immediately lays a wet blanket over Danish director Kasper Barfoed's English-language debut and keeps it firmly in place until the final fade-out.
For the first half, Bay is completely dialed into this material, his frat boy sense of humor and overblown visual sensibility complimenting the story and setting.
The second installment in a planned martial-arts trilogy mixes broad comedy and cartoonish action that will appeal to the genre's fans, though crossover potential seems limited.
For half the movie, Black challenges what audiences have come to expect from comic book movies and Marvel movies in particular. But then in the other half, he falls back on the same-old same-old.
Ultimately, Unmade in China is ultimately less about the experience of making a movie in China than it is a chronicle of one director's wounded ego.
The pleasure of the film doesn't lie in the plot; it's all about the sultry, horror-tinged mood that Cassavetes manufactures.
In the end -- for better and for worse -- this is very much Baz Luhrmann's Great Gatsby, a movie that honors the source material, but stays truer to its own creator's vision.
Aftershock's best attribute is the disregard it shows for the safety of its central "heroes" who perish in brutal and generally unexpected ways.

Into Darkness repeatedly and unapologetically sacrifices science-fiction thoughtfulness on the altar of blockbuster "Wow."
Although Erased goes through the motions of its various spy games efficiently enough, you never completely forget that you're watching an imitation of far better movies.

A strained attempt to translate the comic punch of Alexander Payne's brilliant send-up of high-school politics, Election, into the realm of an even more tension-fraught extracurricular activity: drama club.
This entire saga climaxes in an a moment of catharsis that feels remarkably pat and simplistic.
It's a well-executed survival story, but it misses the chance to amount to anything more.
Too much money was spent on this version of the legend of the 47 Ronin for it to be classified as a wholly inept failure. What it does represent, though, is a failure of imagination.
Those hoping for comic fireworks to erupt between the meeting of these grumpy old men will be disappointed.
Thoughtful but uneven attempt to recast a traditional zombie narrative as an Abraham and Isaac metaphor.
Cox must have seen something in this screenplay that encouraged her to film it, but whatever that critical element was, it's not apparent in the finished product.
A father and daughter hit the road to repair their relationship, but end up trying the audience's patience.

Offers solid fight sequences, but little else.
Like the franchise it's clearly inspired by-the Step Up series-ABCD 2 tricks out simple messages with spectacular dance sequences.
The film achieves a level of proficient mediocrity early on and hovers there for the rest of its slender running time.
A movie that seems to have been made out of obligation rather than desire.
The narrative is leaden and lumpy in a way that suggests prolonged script-tinkering.
The heavily hyped marriage between Amy Schumer and Judd Apatow doesn't always result in comedy bliss, but it does frequently provide the gift of belly laughs.
For anyone over the age of 10, this videogame-derived disaster movie will just be a disaster.
Despite likeable performances by the young cast and some resonant moments, this gauzy teen drama is, sadly, paper-thin.
[After an interesting first half, Extinction] consumes its own brains and becomes another mindless creature feature.
[The directors] don't feel the compulsion to [...] expand on any of the information that was likely handed directly to them by the company's public-relations team.
Understandably if disappointingly leery of asking too many difficult questions about [Farley's] life and death.
May tread familiar territory, but at least it does so with great empathy and thoughtfulness.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: What lasting resonance Amy does achieve has less to do with the story that Kapadia assembles and more with the real-life moments he uses as building blocks.
Unfriended proves that you absolutely can make a movie that unfolds entirely on a computer. The question it doesn't answer is why you'd want to.
Beautifully crafted, but empty at its core.
Will Ferrell and Kevin Hart join forces for a fitfully amusing but problematically conceived modern-day version of Trading Places.
Little Accidents strikes the mournful tone of grand tragedy, but the dramatic notes fall flat.
Seriously, if a movie ever deserved a "Buyer Beware" rating, it's Vice-the mash-up of Westworld and Blade Runner that nobody wanted or needed.
Hart himself is his usual affable, amusing self, but if he's set on becoming a comic actor-as opposed to a pure comic-he has to start prioritizing the scripts over the jokes.
A glum, pedestrian attempt at a "real world" musical that ultimately feels as artificial as a ritzy Broadway show.
Strange Magic is an effective argument against the predominance of computer animation as the current industry standard.
A boldly, baldly opportunistic attempt to aid in the group's return to mainstream relevance.
movie_title: Backstreet Boys: Show 'Em What You're Made Of (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Although moments of playful wit abound throughout, Sponge Out of Water is often so nosily frenetic, it verges on being assaultive.
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Jupiter Ascending routinely seems flummoxed by its own mythology and characters.
Flat and formless in execution.
Only fans of the first movie will want to make time for this occasionally inspired, mostly tedious follow-up.
To borrow a lesson from Stephen Colbert, instead of accepting Kung Fu Elliot as truth, you might be better off approaching it as an illustration of "truthiness."
Comedy plus tragedy equals boredom in Adam Carolla's crowdfunded star vehicle.
There are ordinary homages and then there are high-quality cinematic mix tapes like It Follows.
For a movie that has no reason to exist beyond maximizing Disney's back catalogue, Kenneth Branagh's live action Cinderella is an entirely enjoyable piece of fairy tale theater.
The musicians' memories, coupled with the murderers' row of killer tunes that play on the soundtrack, carry you along and recreate a period in the music industry that's long since vanished.
The Hunting Ground directly and, at times, bluntly argues its case, appealing directly to the audiences' sense of moral outrage.
So deprived of laughs (not to mention brains), it makes Meet the Spartans and Vampires Suck look like Airplane! or Hot Shots.
Tracers gifts the world with the mash-up of Oliver Twist and parkour that it never knew it needed, and will justifiably ignore.
The lack of any memorable story elements or overall narrative drive might not be so pronounced if this post-apocalyptic future were even halfway interesting.
A smorgasbord of a musical biopic in which the strength of the individual parts compensates for the flaws of the whole.
Película starts to feel repetitious and hermetically sealed, a prolonged joke that's unsustainable precisely because it's targeted at such an ultra-specific audience.
[Christian Cantamessa has] the eye of a promising director-now he just needs a better script.
A sequel that has no reason to exist is also a movie that has no reason to be seen.
Isao Takahata's 1991 animated feature belatedly arrives on U.S. screens and thankfully hasn't aged a day.
The night is dark and not so full of terrors in "Game of Thrones" star Natalie Dormer's first foray into C-grade J-horror.
Not out there enough to work as gonzo period comedy, and certainly not trenchant enough to succeed as satire, Moonwalkers is an imitation of a real movie.
With one notable exception, the quality of this horror anthology mostly heads in one direction: south.
Early on, Deadpool teases audiences that it's going to lead a comedy-laced comic-book movie revolution, but it ends up joining the superhero establishment.
While it builds to an intriguing thematic question, the dramatic situation at the heart of Tobias Lindholm's war-themed procedural is a little too open-and-shut.
[An] endearingly goofy gloss on the Old World fantasy spectacles of yesteryear.
A sequel in third act only, 10 Cloverfield Lane successfully switches out monster-movie mayhem for chamber-room chills.
The odd-couple comedy duo of Ferrell & Wahlberg enlivens this mostly tedious comedy, which has hints of a darker, more interesting film lurking underneath.
Although there's technically one more film to go in the four-part Divergent Series, this third installment reveals a franchise already on its last legs.
A contemporary Blair Witch Project knock-off that feels significantly more dated than the film it's inspired by.
More like Headache-Inducing Henry.
Karyn Kusama's quietly chilling direction enlivens a somewhat plodding housebound thriller.
Jeremy Saulnier's wickedly entertaining follow-up to Blue Ruin makes a big impression by staying small.
Errol Morris appears to serve as the inspiration for Nicolas Steiner's documentary, which possesses some of that director's artistry but lacks his inquisitive spirit.
Keanu is proof positive that Key & Peele are one of the great contemporary comedy duos, even if the feature surrounding them is little more than a shaggy-cat story.
The Marvel blockbuster machine keeps on trucking with a double-sized new issue of Captain America that packs enough punch to distract from its grinding plot mechanics.
The English-language debut of Greek director Yorgos Lanthimos is built on a terrific premise, but some cracks appear in the foundation by the final act.
Zack Snyder's wearying superhero opus may be slugged "Dawn of Justice," but it's the twilight of any hope that the filmmaker will find the fun in the DC Universe.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: If [Concussion] serves any purpose at all, it's as a reminder that Will Smith is an A-grade movie star, even in C-grade material.
Eight too often feels wearying, a film of modest ambition made by a director with unlimited resources.
Strives to unite old and new generations of Star Wars fans and mostly succeeds.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A standout star turn from Elisabeth Moss enlivens and deepens Alex Ross Perry's extended Roman Polanski homage.
Like our good neighbor to the north, this first-person documentary is genial, amusing and a little bit dull.
Cooties struggles to fill 90 minutes with a premise that could support, at most, five minutes of great content.
Robert De Niro soars in Nancy Meyers' latest-too bad the movie itself only intermittently achieves liftoff.
A diverting animated sequel that, believe it or not, boasts one of Adam Sandler's most affecting performances.
Within the guise of a rarefied ode to silent movies, Maddin may have made his most commercial film.
Oh, what short form sci-fi master Ray Bradbury would have made of this overlong short story!
War is (a beautiful) hell in Cary Joji Fukunaga's disconcertingly picturesque combat film.
While there may be some slight stiffness in the storytelling joints, Guillermo del Toro's Gothic love story is a visually ravishing delight.
A sweet, well-meaning confection that doesn't provide a lot of genre nourishment.
Despite working from extraordinary subject matter-Edgar Allan Poe's various tales of the macabre-too many entries in this animated anthology are disappointingly ordinary.
One of the most invigorating portraits of democracy in action to come along in recent memory.
More a doodle than a fully formed documentary, this chronicle of a modern-day musical maestro nevertheless dances to an intriguing tune.
[A] slick, efficient and utterly banal piece of global cinema product.
M. Night Shyamalan's first foray into found-footage territory conjures up a few scares, but otherwise operates on autopilot.
A warm-hearted, if somewhat superficial, exploration of how great music crosses borders, composed in the key of Buena Vista Social Club.
The reigning YA franchise champ laces up for one final round, and (mostly) manages to go out on top.
Gentle to a fault, this quiet adaptation of the Finnish comic strip will likely only delight the Moomin faithful.

A perceptive, if sometimes heavy-handed, drama about love and marriage.
It's the filmmakers' own lack of imagination that will likely doom this would-be franchise to an early grave.

movie_review_blurb: Jolie has clearly demonstrated she has the chops to shoot a good movie; her next challenge is to make a personal one.
An impassioned lead performance and timely parallels to contemporary social issues enliven and elevate this otherwise somewhat routine biopic.

Beneath the grandstanding, the film is a provocative, nuanced and even empathetic account of one woman's attempts to understand and perhaps eventually reconcile the mechanical and emotional factors that are bound up in sex.

Timely subject matter and a compelling story ultimately win over uneven performances.
Honestly, the only meaning I took away from The Secret Life of Walter Mitty is that it makes Simple Jack look like Citizen Kane.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Clearly calculated to win Oscars, August: Osage County instead feels more worthy of a Razzie or two.
If you're looking for a cure to the common English period prestige picture, Ralph Fiennes's The Invisible Woman fits the bill nicely.

An agreeable way to kill 80 minutes.

A nobly-intentioned feature that lacks the discipline and focus to unite its disparate elements into an effective whole.

movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

A remarkable you-are-there recreation of the past decade of American covert affairs.

in its pleasantly low-key way, this is as inconsequential and instantly forgettable a movie as a bombastic blockbuster like Transformers: Dark of the Moon.

One of my favorites of this young year and among the most unique features I've seen from an American animation house in recent memory.
